1.04 - OATHS AND BONDS. 
Elected and appointed officials shall take and file the official oath within 10 days after notice of their election or appointment as provided in §62.09(4)(a), Wis. Stats., and shall execute and file the official bond as required by State Statutes and this Municipal Code. 
(1)  BOND OF TREASURER. (Rep. & recr. #17-O927) 
(a)  Duplicate Tax Bond Eliminated. The City elects not to give the bond on the Treasurer provided for by §70.67(1), Wis. Stats. 
(b)  City Liable for Default. Pursuant to §70.67(2), Wis. Stats., the City shall pay, if the Treasurer fails to do so, all State and County taxes required by law to be paid to the County Treasurer. 
1.05 - REMOVALS. 
(1)  ELECTED OFFICIALS. Elected officials may be removed by the City Council as provided in §17.12(1)(a) or as provided by §17.16, Wis. Stats. 
(2)  APPOINTED OFFICIALS. Appointed officials may be removed as provided in §§17.12(1)(c) and 17.16, Wis. Stats. 
1.06 - VACANCIES. 
(1)  HOW OCCURRING. Vacancies in elective and appointive positions are caused as provided in §§17.03 and 17.035, Wis. Stats. 
(2)  HOW FILLED. Vacancies in elective and appointive offices shall be filled as provided in §17.23, Wis. Stats. 
1.07 - SALARIES. 
The salaries of all elected and appointed officials, including members of boards and commissions, shall be as determined by the City Council from time to time, provided the salary of the Mayor and members of the Council shall not be increased during their terms of office. (See §66.196, Wis. Stats.) 
1.08 - RECEIPT OF GIFTS AND GRATUITIES. 
(1)  RESTRICTED. No City employee or official shall receive or offer to receive, either directly or indirectly, any gift, gratuity or other thing of value which he/she is not authorized to receive from any person who: 
(a)  Has or is seeking to obtain contractual or other business or financial relationships with the City or City Council; or 
(b)  Conducts operations or activities which are regulated by the City or City Council; or 
(c)  Has interests which may be substantially affected by the City or City Council. 
(2)  PENALTY. The receipt of any gift, gratuity or other thing of value as denoted above is contrary to the public policy of the City and is punishable as provided in §946.12, Wis. Stats. Such conduct shall also be punishable under §25.04 of this Municipal Code. 
1.09 - STANDARD OF CONDUCT. (Cr. #82-0102) 
The purpose of this section is to enable public officials and employees to conduct themselves in a manner that will tend to preserve public confidence in and respect for the government of the City. 
(1)  DEFINITIONS. (Am. #86-0168) The terms used in this section are defined as follows: 
Financial Interest. Any interest which shall yield, directly or indirectly, a monetary or other material benefit to the officer or employee or to any person employing or retaining the services of the officer or employee. 
Personal Interest. Any interest arising from blood or marriage relationships or from close business or political associations, whether or not any financial interest is involved. 
Public Employee. Any person excluded from the definition of a public officer who is employed by the City or by the City Water and Electric Utility. 
Public Official. All of those persons defined in §62.09, Wis. Stats., and all members of boards, commissions and agencies established or appointed by the Mayor or City Council, whether paid or unpaid. 
(2)  CONFLICT OF INTEREST. 
(a)  Financial or Personal Interest. No official or employee, either on his/her own behalf or on behalf of any other person, shall have any financial or personal interest in any business or transaction with any public body in the City unless he/she shall first make full public disclosure of the nature and extent of such interest. 
(b)  Disclosure and Disqualification. Whenever the performance of his/her official duties requires any official or employee to deliberate and vote on any matter involving or appearing to involve his/her financial or personal interest, he/she shall publicly disclose the nature and extent of such interest and disqualify himself/herself from voting. 
(c)  Incompatible Employment. 
1.  No official or employee shall engage in private employment with, or render service for, any private person who has business transactions with any public body of the City unless he/she shall first make full public disclosure of the nature and extent of such employment or services. 
2.  No person may simultaneously hold a public office and be a public employee. Any officer/employee holding both an office and employment position in violation of this subsection on the effective date of September 25, 1986, may complete his/her current term of office without being required to resign from either the incompatible office or employment position. (Cr. #86-0168) 
(d)  Representation of Private Persons. No official or employee shall use or attempt to use his/her official position to secure special privileges or exemptions for himself/herself or others except as may be otherwise provided by law. 
(e)  Gifting. No official or employee or immediate member of such person's family shall accept from anyone, any gift, whether in the form of money, thing, favor, loan or promise, hospitality or entertainment that would not be offered or given to him/her if he/she were not an official or employee. 
(f)  Privileged Information. No official or employee shall use or permit the use of any privileged or nonpublic information obtained in the course of his/her official duties to advance the financial or personal interest of himself/herself or any other person. 
OFFICIALS 

1.10 - MAYOR AND ALDERMEN. 
(1)  ELECTION AND TERM. See §1.02. 
(2)  DUTIES AND POWERS. 
(a)  Mayor. See §62.09(8), Wis. Stats. 
(b)  City Council. The Aldermen shall constitute the City Council and shall have such duties and powers as are enumerated in Ch. 62, Wis. Stats., and elsewhere in the statutes. 
(c)  Police Powers. See §62.09(14), Wis. Stats. 
(3)  AUTHORITY. The City Council shall have all powers of the City not specifically given to some other body or officer. Except as otherwise provided by law, the City Council shall have the management and control of the City property, finances, highways, streets, utilities and the public service and may act for the government and good order of the City, for its commercial benefit and for the health, safety, welfare and convenience of the public and may carry its powers into effect by license, regulation, suppression, borrowing, taxation, special assessment, appropriation, imposition of forfeiture and other necessary or convenient means. The City Council may appoint such officers from time to time as may be deemed necessary for the benefit of the community. The powers hereby conferred shall be in addition to all other grants and shall be limited only by express language. 
(4)  OTHER PROVISIONS. See also Chapter 2 of this Municipal Code. 
1.11 - ADMINISTRATOR-TREASURER. 
(1)  APPOINTMENT. See §1.03(1) of this chapter. 
(2)  DUTIES AS TREASURER. The Treasurer shall perform those duties prescribed in §62.09(9), Wis. Stats., and such other duties as the Council may prescribe. The Treasurer shall be the investment officer for the City. 
(3)  DEPUTY. The Treasurer may in writing, filed with the Mayor and in the office of the City Clerk, appoint a deputy treasurer who shall act under his/her direction and in his/her absence or disability and who shall, in case of a vacancy, perform his/her duties. The deputy shall receive such compensation as the Council determines. 
(4)  DUTIES AS ADMINISTRATOR. The administrative duties and responsibilities of the City Administrator shall be prescribed from time to time by the Mayor and the Council, provided these duties do not usurp the duties or functions that are required by State law to be performed by the City boards, commissions and other City officers or department officials. The Administrator shall have the following specific duties and responsibilities: 
(a)  He/she shall be responsible for effectuating all actions of the Council which require administrative implementation or where the Mayor or the Council have directed him/her to act. 
(b)  He/she shall be responsible for directing, coordinating and expediting the activities of all City departments except where such authority is vested by State law in officers, boards and commissions. Such responsibilities shall include making or directing such studies as are necessary to determine or bring about the most economical and efficient operation of such departments and their programs as deemed necessary; however, the Administrator shall not control the activities within the various departments, such functional departmental activites to remain under the direct control of the department heads. 
(c)  He/she shall direct and control, through appropriate organizational channels, the efficient performance of all City employees' duties. After the appropriate screening and selection process has been followed, the Administrator shall submit recommendations to the Mayor and the Council for appointees to vacancies in any city positions or offices of the City not required by law or ordinance to be otherwise selected. 
(d)  He/she shall be responsible for developing budgeting procedures and preparing or supervising the preparation of the annual operating budget. The Administrator shall also be responsible for coordinating financial and economic data for the City's long-range financial plan. In addition, the Administrator shall make such reports as the Mayor and the Council may require as to the current status of budgeted items and shall review and report to the Mayor and the Council any variations in the operation of the City budget. 
(e)  He/she shall serve as personnel officer for the City and shall be responsible for the development and administration of standardized personnel policies and procedures, subject to Council approval and in accordance with all prior ordinances relating to tenure of certain City positions. 
(f)  He/she shall be responsible for developing and implementing a standardized purchasing policy and procedure for the City and shall be responsible for supervising the purchasing of all supplies, materials and equipment. 
(g)  He/she shall review proposed and pending County, State and federal legislation and shall report to the Mayor and the Council on its effect upon the City. In addition, the Administrator shall appear on the City's behalf at all legislative and administrative hearings as directed by the Mayor or the Council. 
(h)  He/she shall submit, when necessary, recommendations and suggestions for improving the health, safety or welfare of the residents of the City and shall coordinate a system of communications among and with the Mayor and the Council as well as with the general public. This shall include the establishment of procedures for the facilitation of communications between citizens and the City to assure that complaints, grievances, recommendations and other matters receive the prompt attention of a responsible official and are expeditiously resolved. 
(i)  He/she shall keep informed concerning current developments in the field of municipal administration and the availability of State and federal funds for local purposes. 
(j)  He/she shall work closely with all department heads to assure that they and other City employees receive adequate opportunities for training within budgetary allowances prescribed by the Council to improve their knowledge and skills. The Administrator shall act as the approving authority for all requests by City employees to attend conferences, meetings, training schools, etc., pertaining to their employment. 
(k)  He/she shall in coordination with the Mayor and the City Clerk prepare the agenda for all meetings of the Council, together with such supporting data as may be required, provided nothing herein shall be construed to give the Administrator authority to limit or prevent matters from being considered by the Council. The Administrator shall attend all meetings of the Council, boards and commissions, assisting the Mayor and the City Clerk as required in the performance of their duties. 
(l)  He/she shall have charge and management of the City utilities, subject to the general control and supervision of the City Council. (Rep. & recr. #88-0198) 
(m)  The City Administrator shall serve as the manager of all economic development programs of the City and shall be responsible for coordinating the activities of the Economic Development Planning Commission established under §1.43 of this Municipal Code. (Cr. #87-0177) 
(n)  The City Administrator shall have the authority to appoint all heads of departments, all subordinate City officials and all City employees, with the exception of those appointed under §1.03 or other sections of this Code where the appointing authority is otherwise specified. Regardless of by whom appointed, the Administrator shall have the authority, when necessary for the good of the City service, to suspend or discharge heads of departments, subordinate City officials or employees of the City, except as the Administrator may authorize the head of a department or office to appoint, suspend or discharge subordinates in such department or office. (Cr. #96-0369) 
(5)  SELECTION. The appointment of the City Administrator shall be made solely on merit with due consideration given to his/her training, experience, ability and general qualifications and fitness for performing the duties of the office. 
(6)  COOPERATION. All officers and employees of the City shall cooperate with and assist the City Administrator so that the City functions efficiently. 
1.12 - ASSESSOR. 
(1)  ELECTION AND TERM. See §1.03(1). 
(2)  APPLICABLE STATUTE. See §62.09(1), Wis. Stats. 
(3)  DUTIES AND POWERS. 
(a)  Statutes . See §§70.12, 70.13, 70.17, 70.18, 70.23, 70.29, 70.30, 70.32, 70.325, 70.34, 70.345, 70.35, 70.365, 70.43, 70.44, 70.45, 70.48, 70.49, 70.50, 70.501 and 70.503, Wis. Stats., in particular. 
(b)  Other Duties Prescribed by Law . He/she shall perform such other duties as shall be prescribed by State law, supervisory personnel of the State Department of Revenue and the City Council, including attendance at all meetings of the Board of Review. 
1.13 - ATTORNEY. 
(1)  APPOINTMENT. See §1.03(2) of this chapter. 
(2)  QUALIFICATION. The City Attorney shall be a member in good standing of the State Bar of Wisconsin. 
(3)  DUTIES. The City Attorney shall have the duties and responsibilities prescribed in §62.09(12), Wis. Stats., and such other duties as the Mayor and Council may prescribe. 
(4)  ASSISTANT CITY ATTORNEY. (Am. #17-O912) Notwithstanding the provisions of §62.09(12)(f) the Mayor may appoint an Assistant City Attorney, subject to confirmation by the Common Council, who may perform his/her duties and for whose acts he/she shall be responsible to the City and who shall have such other duties as the City Attorney may prescribe. The Assistant City Attorney shall be paid such compensation as the Council shall determine from time to time. 
1.14 - BUILDING INSPECTOR. (Rep. & recr. #84-0131) 
(1)  BUILDING INSPECTION DEPARTMENT. The Building Inspection Department shall be a division of the Engineering Department and the Building Inspector shall be responsible to the City Engineer. 
(2)  OFFICES OF BUILDING, PLUMBING AND ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR COMBINED. The offices of Building, Plumbing and Electrical Inspector may be combined as provided by §14.03(4) of this Municipal Code and the person appointed as Building Inspector shall perform the duties of each of such offices. 
1.15 - CLERK. 
(1)  APPOINTMENT. See §1.03(1) of this chapter. 
(2)  DUTIES. The Clerk shall perform those duties prescribed in §62.09(11), Wis. Stats., and such other duties as the Council may prescribe. 
(3)  DEPUTY. The Clerk may, in writing, filed with the Mayor and in the office of the Clerk, appoint a deputy clerk who shall act under his/her direction and in his/her absence or disability and who shall, in case of a vacancy, perform his/her duties. The deputy shall receive such compensation as the Council determines. 
1.16 - COMPTROLLER. 
(1)  APPOINTMENT. See §1.03(2) of this chapter. 
(2)  DUTIES. (Am. #87-0183) The Comptroller shall be required to perform only those duties as may be prescribed by resolution of the City Council. 
1.17 - EMERGENCY GOVERNMENT DIRECTOR. 
(1)  APPOINTMENT. See §1.03(2) of this chapter. 
(2)  CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT. The Emergency Government Director shall receive such salary as may be authorized by the Council. He/she shall take and file an official oath. 
(3)  DEPUTY AND ASSISTANT DIRECTORS. Deputy and assistant directors may be appointed by the Director, subject to the approval of the Emergency Government Commission. Such appointees shall receive such compensation as may be determined by the Council. 
(4)  DUTIES AND AUTHORITY. 
(a)  The Director shall be the executive head of the emergency government organization and shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration and operation of such organization, subject to the direction and control of the Mayor and the Council. He/she shall coordinate all activities for emergency government within the City and maintain liaison and cooperate with emergency government agencies and organizations of other political subdivisions and of the State and federal governments, shall participate in county and State emergency government activities upon request and shall have such additional authority, duties and responsibilities as may be determined by the Council. 
(b)  The Director shall prepare a comprehensive general plan for the emergency government of the City and present such plan to the Council for its approval and all emergency government forces of the City shall perform the duties and functions assigned to them by the approved plan. The plan may be modified from time to time in a like manner. 
(c)  The Director shall in cooperation with City departments affected organize, recruit and train any personnel that may be required on a volunteer basis to carry out the emergency government plans of the City and State and conduct such test drills as authorized by the State. 
1.18 - ENGINEER. 
(1)  APPOINTMENT. See §1.03(1) of this chapter. 
(2)  DUTIES. The City Engineer shall perform the duties prescribed in §62.14(7), Wis. Stats., and such other duties as the Council may prescribe. 
1.19 - FIRE CHIEF. (Am. #92-0289) 
(1)  APPOINTMENT AND TERM. The Fire Chief shall be a full-time officer, appointed by the Police and Fire Commission, who shall hold office during good behavior, subject to suspension or removal by the Commission for cause. The Fire Chief shall be under the direct supervision of the Director of Public Safety. The Director of Public Safety may also be Fire Chief. 
(2)  GENERAL DUTIES. The Fire Chief shall perform such duties as are prescribed in Ch. 5 of this Municipal Code and such other duties as may be prescribed by the Director of Public Safety, the City Council or both. 
(3)  DUTY OF REPORTING. The Fire Chief shall make annual reports to the Director of Public Safety and the City Council on the condition of the Fire Department and shall recommend to the Director of Public Safety the purchase of such supplies and apparatus for the Fire Department as may be deemed necessary. The Fire Chief shall, in addition to the making of the annual reports to the Director of Public Safety and City Council, make and attach to each report a brief summary or recapitulation showing activities of the previous year as well as the number and salaries of the members of the Department for the previous year. 
1.20 - POLICE CHIEF. (Am. #92-0289) 
(1)  APPOINTMENT AND TERM. The Chief of Police shall be appointed by the Police and Fire Commission and shall hold office during good behavior, subject to suspension or removal by such Commission for cause. The Director of Public Safety may also be Chief of Police. 
(2)  GENERAL DUTIES. The Chief of Police shall perform such duties as are prescribed by Ch. 4 of this Municipal Code and such other duties as may be prescribed by the Director of Public Safety, the City Council or both. 
(3)  DUTY OF REPORTING. The Chief of Police shall turn over daily to the City Treasurer all fees, fines, receipts and all other moneys received by his/her Department. He/she shall also make annual reports to the City Council and all such other reports as are required of him/her by State law and the ordinances of the City. The Chief of Police shall at the time of making his/her report to the Council as to the efficiency of the police force include the number of arrests made and the occasions therefor and such other matters as he/she shall embody in his/her reports, make and attach to each of such reports a brief summary or recapitulation showing the number of policemen and their respective salaries, the total number of arrests made and the occasions therefor and such other matters in brief as he/she deems to be important. 
1.205 - DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SAFETY. (Cr. #92-0289) 
(1)  APPOINTMENT AND TERM. The Director of Public Safety shall be a full-time officer, appointed by the Police and Fire Commission, who shall hold office during good behavior, subject to suspension or removal by the Commission for cause. The Director of Public Safety may also be the Police Chief, Fire Chief or both. 
(2)  GENERAL DUTIES. The Director of Public Safety shall administer the Police and Fire Departments and shall be responsible for the government, efficiency and general good conduct of such Departments. The Director shall assure that the Police and Fire Chiefs perform the duties required of them by this Code and if the Director is also a Chief of either or both Departments, he/she shall perform the duties required of him/her in that capacity. The Director shall have command of the police and fire forces of the City under the direction of the City Council. The Director shall obey all lawful written orders of the City Administrator or the City Council. The Director shall also cause the public peace to be preserved and insure that fire suppression and prevention is accomplished, enforce all laws and ordinances of the City and statutes of the State of which the Police and Fire Departments must take cognizance and whenever any violation thereof shall come to the Director's knowledge, he/she shall cause the requisite complaint to be made and procure the evidence for the successful prosecution of the offender. 
(3)  POWERS. The Director of Public Safety shall have the power to assign personnel of either or both the Police and Fire Departments, to prescribe, promulgate and enforce rules and regulations, general orders and special orders for the members of the Departments which shall, however, not be inconsistent with the ordinances of the City or the laws of the State. 
(4)  APPOINTMENTS AND PROMOTIONS. The Director of Public Safety shall make all appointments and promotions in the Departments pursuant to §62.13, Wis. Stats. This authority does not include the appointment of Chiefs of the respective Departments which, pursuant to §62.13(3), Wis. Stats., shall be made by the Board of Police and Fire Commissioners. 
(5)  TRAINING. The Director of Public Safety shall have the supervision and control of the proper training and education of all members of the Departments and may require any or all members to attend selected police and fire training schools or programs for the attainment of the highest possible degree of development and accomplishment in the Police and Fire Departments. 
(6)  ABSENCE OF THE DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC SAFETY. During the absence of the Director of Public Safety, the Chiefs of the respective Departments, if the Director is not the Chief, shall perform all the duties of the Director of Public Safety, except to appoint or promote members of the Departments or to dismiss personnel, commit City resources, allocate funds or implement policy. If the Director of Public Safety is also a chief, the next subordinate officer in rank as established by the rules and regulations of the Department shall perform such duties for the Department. 
(7)  DUTY OF REPORTING. The Director shall assure that the duties of reporting required by this Municipal Code of the Chief of Police, if he/she is not the Chief of Police, and the Fire Chief, if he/she is not the Fire Chief, be performed. 
1.21 - PUBLIC WORKS, DIRECTOR OF. 
(1)  SELECTION. The appointment of the Director of Public Works shall be made solely on merit, upon the basis of training, experience, administrative ability, efficiency and general qualifications and fitness for performing the duties of the position. 
(2)  TERM. See §1.03(1). 
(3)  COMPENSATION. The Director of Public Works shall receive such compensation and expense allowance as the Council shall prescribe from time to time. 
(4)  OTHER EMPLOYMENT PROHIBITED. The Director of Public Works shall engage in no other remunerative employment or activity nor shall he/she undertake any professional, business, industrial or promotional activity for personal pecuniary profit. 
(5)  POWERS AND DUTIES. The Director of Public Works shall have, among others, the following powers and duties: 
(a)  Public Works Administration. (Am. #85-0154) Subject to the direction of the Council and the Board of Public Works, if any, the Director shall be responsible for the administration of all public works and shall have general charge and supervision of all maintenance, repair and construction of streets, alleys, curbs and gutters, sidewalks, bridges, street signs and house numbering, traffic control devices, signs and markings, storm sewers, culverts and drainage facilities, City buildings and structures where the administration, maintenance and repair has not been delegated to others, and all machinery and equipment used in any activity under the Director's control. 
(b)  Sewage. He/she shall manage the sewage treatment plant. 
(c)  Solid Waste. He/she shall have charge of such public services as solid waste collection and disposal, snow and ice removal, street cleaning and flushing, lake level control and such other activities as may be assigned to him/her from time to time by the Council. 
(d)  Records. He/she shall be responsible for the keeping of all records and documents required by law or ordinance for activities under his/her supervision and all such items shall remain the property of the City. 
(e)  Personnel. He/she shall appoint, subject to the approval of the Council, all heads of divisions of the Public Works Department. He/she shall appoint other personnel of all divisions and activities under his/her supervision. All appointments shall be probationary for the first 90 days of continuous employment and shall be made solely on merit, upon the basis of training, experience, ability, integrity and general fitness for the duties to be performed. 
(f)  Suspension of Employment. He/she may suspend or remove any City employee under his/her direction and appointed by him/her during the probationary periods. After the probationary period, he/she may suspend or remove any City employee under his/her direction because of insubordination, misconduct, incompetency, inefficiency or failure to perform duties or to observe the rules and regulations applicable to that position. Any such suspension or removal shall be subject to a hearing before the Council, if requested in writing by the employee involved and filed with the City Clerk within 10 days after such suspension or removal. The determination of the Council shall be final in each case. 
(g)  Reports. He/she shall, from time to time, submit to the Council such suggestions and recommendations as he/she believes advisable for the betterment and more efficient operation of the various divisions and activities under his/her supervision. Not later than February 15 of each year, he/she shall submit to the Council and the Board of Public Works a written report of all divisions and activities under his/her supervision for the preceding calendar year. 
1.23 - DIRECTOR OF PARKS AND RECREATION. (Rep. & recr. #85-0154) 
(1)  APPOINTMENT AND TERM. See §1.03(1) of this chapter. 
(2)  DUTIES. 
(a)  General. The Director of Parks and Recreation shall implement Parks and Recreation Board policy and supervise programs established by such Board. The Director shall be responsible to the City Council. 
(b)  Recreation Programs. The Director of Parks and Recreation shall plan, organize, publicize, supervise and evaluate all programs sponsored or cosponsored by the Department. The Director shall act as advisor for Department programs and assure that such programs are conducted within the framework of Department policy. In addition to conducting established programs, the Director shall initiate new programs which the Director and/or the Board feel are in the best interests of the City. 
(c)  Parks. Subject to the direction of the City Council, the Director shall have general charge and supervision of all parks and recreational facilities, including the maintenance and repair of any structures located therein. 
(d)  Trees and Plantings. The Director shall have general charge and supervision of the planting and maintenance of trees and shrubs in parks and on tree borders, public streets and other public property. See §8.09 of this Municipal Code. 
(e)  Personnel. After consultation with the City Administrator, the Director shall advertise for and seek employees deemed necessary for the administration and supervision of City parks and recreation programs. The Director shall conduct interviews, initiate and terminate employment, conduct training sessions and evaluate all personnel of the Department. 
(f)  Budget. The Director shall be responsible to the Board for the income and expenditures of the Department and shall operate the Department within the funds allotted. The Director shall, annually, submit a budget to the Board for its analysis and approval. The approved budget shall be submitted to the City Administrator by August 1 of each year. 
(g)  Management of Other Funds. The Director shall serve as Treasurer for the organizations affiliated with the Department or trust funds held by the Department. The Director and Secretary shall be bonded through the City. 
(h)  Equipment and Supplies. The Director shall be responsible for the selection, purchase, storage and maintenance of all equipment and supplies necessary to perform the duties set forth above. 
1.24 - UTILITIES, SUPERINTENDENT OF. 
(1)  APPOINTMENT AND TERM. (Am. #88-0198) A Superintendent of Utilities may be appointed by the Council for an indefinite term. 
(2)  DUTIES. See §13.03 of this Municipal Code. 
1.25 - MUNICIPAL COURT AND MUNICIPAL JUDGE. (Rep. & recr. #17-O911) 
(1)  MUNICIPAL COURT CREATED. There is hereby created and established a Municipal Court under the provisions of Ch. 755, Wis. Stats., for the City of Oconomowoc, Village of Oconomowoc Lake, Village of Dousman, Town of Delafield, Village of Nashotah, Town of Lisbon, Town of Merton, Village of Sussex, Village of Hartland, Village of Lac LaBelle, Town of Oconomowoc, Village of Summit, Village of Chenequa, Town of Erin, Village of Merton, Village of Sullivan, Village of Johnson Creek (Contract Member), Town of Ixonia (Contract Member) and Town of Ottawa (Contract Member) or so many of those municipalities which enact an ordinance identical to this section pursuant to §755.01(4), Wis. Stats. 
(2)  MUNICIPAL JUDGE. Such court shall be under the jurisdiction of and presided over by a Municipal Judge, who shall be an attorney licensed to practice law in Wisconsin and who shall reside in one of the following Municipalities: City of Oconomowoc, Village of Oconomowoc Lake, Village of Dousman, Town of Delafield, Village of Nashotah, Town of Lisbon, Town of Merton, Village of Sussex, Village of Hartland, Village of Lac LaBelle, Town of Oconomowoc, Village of Summit, Village of Chenequa, Town of Erin, Village of Merton, Village of Sullivan, Village of Johnson Creek, Town of Ixonia or Town of Ottawa or those municipalities which enact an ordinance identical to this section and enter into an agreement pursuant to §66.0301, Wis. Stats., for the joint exercise of the power granted under §755.01, Wis. Stats. Such Municipal Judge shall be elected at large in the spring election for a term of 4 years commencing May 1. All candidates for the position of Municipal Judge shall be nominated by nomination papers as provided in §8.10, Wis. Stats., and selection at a primary election if such is held as provided in §8.11, Wis. Stats. The Town Board of the Town of Delafield shall provide for a primary election whenever 3 or more candidates file nomination papers for such position of Municipal Judge as provided in §8.11(1)(a), Wis. Stats., and such primary election shall be held on the third Tuesday of February as provided in §5.02(22), Wis. Stats. 
(3)  ELECTIONS. The Municipal Clerk of each municipality shall see to the compliance with §§5.58(1c), 5.60(1)(b), 5.60(2), 7.10(1)(a), 7.60(4)(a) and 8.10(6)(bm), Wis. Stats., to provide for the election of a Municipal Judge under §755.01(4), Wis. Stats. 
(4)  OATH AND BOND. The Judge shall, after his election or appointment to fill a vacancy, take and file the official oath as prescribed in §757.02(1), Wis. Stats., and at the same time execute and file an official bond in the amount of $5,000.00. The Judge shall not act until his oath and bond have been filed as required by §19.01(4)(c), Wis. Stats., and the requirements of §755.03(2), Wis. Stats., have been complied with. 
(5)  SALARY. The salary of the Municipal Judge shall be fixed by the governing bodies of the municipalities that created and established this Municipal Court, which shall be in lieu of fees and costs. No salary shall be paid for any time during his/her term during which such Judge has not executed his official bond or official oath, as required by §755.03, Wis. Stats., and filed pursuant to §19.01(4)(c), Wis. Stats. The municipalities may by separate ordinances, resolutions, or through the budget process, allocate funds for the administration of the Municipal Court pursuant to §66.0301, Wis. Stats. 
(6)  JURISDICTION. The Municipal Judge of the Municipal Court shall have such jurisdiction as provided by §§755.045 and 755.05, Wis. Stats., and as otherwise provided by State law. The Municipal Judge is authorized to issue inspection warrants under §66.0119, Wis. Stats. 
(7)  LOCATION AND HOURS. The Municipal Court shall be held in the Council Chambers of the City of Oconomowoc City Hall at 174 E. Wisconsin Avenue, Oconomowoc, Wisconsin. The Municipal Court shall be open at such times as determined by the Municipal Judge. 
(8)  FINES AND FORFEITURES. The Municipal Judge may impose punishment and sentences as provided by §800.09, Wis. Stats., and as provided in the ordinances of the following municipalities: City of Oconomowoc, Village of Oconomowoc Lake, Village of Dousman, Town of Delafield, Village of Nashotah, Town of Lisbon, Town of Merton, Village of Sussex, Village of Hartland, Village of Lac LaBelle, Town of Oconomowoc, Village of Summit, Village of Chenequa, Town of Erin, Village of Merton, Village of Sullivan, Village of Johnson Creek, Town of Ixonia or Town of Ottawa. All forfeitures, fees, penalty assessments and costs shall be paid to the Treasurer of the municipality within which the case arose within 7 days after receipt of the money by the Municipal Judge or other court personnel. At the time of the payment, the Municipal Judge shall report to the Treasurer the title of the action, the offense for which a forfeiture was imposed and the total amount of the forfeiture, fees, penalty assessment and costs, if any. 
(9)  STIPULATIONS AND DEPOSITS IN MUNICIPAL COURT. The Municipal Court herein established shall be operated pursuant to and in compliance with the provisions of Ch. 800, Wis. Stats., and, where applicable, other provisions of the Wis. Stats. as referred to in subsection (10) below. The Municipal Judge shall establish in accordance with §800.037, Wis. Stats., a schedule of deposits for violations of City, Village and Town ordinances, resolutions and by-laws, except traffic regulations which are and shall be governed by §345.26, Wis. Stats., and boating violations which are, and shall be governed by §§23.66 and 23.67, Wis. Stats. Such deposit schedule shall be approved by the respective governing bodies of the municipalities creating and establishing this Court and shall be posted in the office of the Municipal Court Clerk and the police departments of the respective communities. 
(10)  PROCEDURE IN MUNICIPAL COURT. The procedure in Municipal Court shall be as provided by this section and State law including, but not excluding because of enumeration Chs. 66, 345, 751, 755, 757 and 800, Wis. Stats. 
(11)  CONTEMPT PROCEDURES. 
(a)  The Municipal Judge may impose a sanction authorized under §800.12(2), Wis. Stats., for contempt of court, as defined in §785.01(1), Wis. Stats., in accordance with the procedures under §785.03, Wis. Stats. 
(b)  The Municipal Judge may impose a forfeiture for contempt under §800.12(1), Wis. Stats., in an amount not to exceed $50.00 or, upon nonpayment of the forfeiture and the penalty assessment under §757.05, Wis. Stats., a jail sentence not to exceed 7 days. 
(12)  The Municipal Court hereby established shall not be abolished while the §755.01(4), Wis. Stats., agreement is in effect. 
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 

1.30 - ARCHITECTURAL COMMISSION. 
(1)  ORGANIZATION: TERMS. 
(a)  The Architectural Commission shall consist of 5 members appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the council, for 2-year terms. The terms of the members shall be established so that 3 members are appointed in one year and 2 members are appointed in the alternate year. The Commission shall meet on call. (Am. #80-56) 
(b)  At least 3 members of the Commission shall be persons who are qualified by experience and training to pass upon design and architecture and upon matters pertaining to building construction and safety. An established builder, building contractor, registered professional engineer practicing in the field of building or building design, or a state licensed architect shall qualify as such member. (Am. #02-0533) 
(2)  DUTIES. The Commission shall have the duties as prescribed in §17.703 of this Municipal Code. (Am. #02-0533; Am. #13-O841) 
1.31 - RESERVED. 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ordinance No. 02-0533, adopted Aug. 6, 2002, repealed §1.31 which pertained to the Board of Building Appeals. 
1.32 - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS COMMISSION. 
(1)  HOW CONSTITUTED. The Capital Improvements Commission shall be composed of the City Administrator-Treasurer. Who shall be chairman of the Commission, and the Director of Public Works, Mayor, Planning Consultant, Finance Committee and a member of the Plan Commission, who shall be appointed annually by the Mayor. 
(2)  POWERS AND DUTIES. In addition to the responsibilities vested in such Commission by the State statutes and the directives of the City Council, the Commission shall recommend methods of financing for the projects in which it is involved. 
1.33 - ELECTRICAL COMMISSION. 
(1)  HOW CONSTITUTED. The Electrical Commission shall consist of 5 members appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council. The Commissioners shall be appointed for 3-year terms commencing May 1 in the year in which they are appointed in such manner as to effect the appointment of 3 members one year and 2 members the next year. 
(2)  PROCEDURE. Three members of the Commission shall constitute quorum for business; but no recommendation for the issuance, modification, suspension or revocation of a license shall be adopted except by a majority of all members of the Commission. 
(3)  DUTIES. The Commission shall have the duties and authority provided in §§14.30 through 14.36. 
1.34 - EMERGENCY GOVERNMENT COMMISSION. 
(1)  ORGANIZATION. The Emergency Government Commission shall consist of the Mayor and as many additional members as the Council shall determine by resolution. Such additional members shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, and shall serve without compensation. The Mayor shall serve as chairman of the Commission, and the Emergency Government Director shall serve as secretary of the Commission. 
(2)  DUTIES. The Commission shall be an advisory and planning group and shall advise the Mayor, the Director and the Council on all matters pertaining to emergency government. The Commission shall meet upon the call of the chair. 
1.35 - LIBRARY BOARD. (Rep. & recr. #96-0365) 
(1)  ORGANIZATION; TERMS. 
(a)  The Library Board shall consist of 7 members total, appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for 3-year terms. Members shall be residents of the municipality, except that not more than 2 members may be residents of towns adjacent to the municipality. The school district administrator or the administrator's representative shall be a member of such board. Each term shall commence May l in the year of appointment. Not more than one member of the Council shall at any one time be a member of the board. The Council exercises the authority granted in §43.54(3), Wis. Stats., and provides that the statutorily-required 9 members be reduced so that the number of appointive members of the Library Board is 7. 
(b)  No compensation shall be paid to the members of the Library Board for their services, except members may be reimbursed for their actual and necessary expenses incurred in performing duties outside the City if so authorized by the Library Board. 
(c)  A majority of the membership of the Library Board shall constitute a quorum. 
(2)  DUTIES AND POWERS. The Library Board shall have the duties and powers as prescribed in §43.58, Wis. Stats. 
1.36 - PLAN COMMISSION. 
(1)  HOW CONSTITUTED. (Am. #11-O794) 
(a)  The Plan Commission shall consist of the Mayor, who shall be its presiding officer, the City Engineer, an alderman and 4 resident citizen members, not more than 2 of whom shall reside in the same aldermanic district. Citizen members shall be persons of recognized experience and qualifications. 
(b)  The alderman member of the Commission shall be appointed by the Common Council in April of each year. 
(c)  The resident citizen members shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Common Council, for 3-year terms in such manner as to affect the appointment of at least one of the members every year. 
(d)  Plan Consultant. A plan consultant shall be a nonvoting member of the Commission and shall assist the Commission in the execution of its powers and duties as prescribed in §17.702 of the Municipal Code. (Am. #13-O841) 
(2)  VACANCIES. Vacancies other than ex-officio shall be filled by appointment for the remainder of the unexpired term in the same manner as appointments for the full term. 
(3)  COMPENSATION AND OATH. No member shall receive compensation for services on the Commission. Citizen members shall take the official oath required by §19.01, Wis. Stats., which shall be filed with the City Clerk. 
(4)  STAFF. The Plan Commission may employ experts and such staff as may be necessary and may pay for their services and such other expenses as may be necessary and proper, within the limits of the budget established by the Council or with funds placed at its disposal through gift, subject to confirmation of the person or persons so employed by the Council, and subject further to any ordinance or resolution enacted by the Council. As far as possible, the Commission shall utilize the services of existing City officials and employees. 
1.37 - POLICE AND FIRE COMMISSION. 
(1)  The Police and Fire Commission shall consist of 5 members, 3 of whom shall constitute a quorum. The Mayor shall annually, between the last Monday of April and the first Monday of May, appoint in writing, to be filed with the Secretary of the Commission, one member for a 5-year term. All appointments shall be subject to confirmation by the Council. No appointment shall be made which will result in more than 3 members of the Board belonging to the same political party. All members shall be residents of the City and shall maintain residency during their term. Members of the Board shall serve without compensation. The Board shall keep records of its proceedings. (Am. #06-O653; #07-O704) 
(2)  In addition to the members provided for in sub. (1), the Mayor shall appoint, for a term of one year, subject to confirmation by the Council, one alderman to serve with the Board as an ex officio nonvoting member. 
1.38 - PUBLIC WORKS, BOARD OF. 
(1)  HOW CONSTITUTED. (Am. #88-0198) Pursuant to §62.14, Wis. Stats., the City dispenses with the Board of Public Works. The duties and powers of such Board shall be exercised by the Public Services Committee, except as to the City utilities, in which case the duties and powers of the Board of Public Works shall be exercised by the City Council. 
(2)  DUTIES. The Public Services Committee, when acting as the Board of Public Works, shall perform such duties as are prescribed in Ch. 62, Wis. Stats., and such other duties as the Council imposes from time to time. 
1.39 - PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD. (Rep. & recr. #85-0154) 
(1)  CREATED; HOW CONSTITUTED. 
(a)  There is hereby created an Advisory Board to oversee the Parks and Recreation programs of the City, which Board shall be known as the Parks and Recreation Board. The Parks and Recreation Board shall consist of 8 members appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council. Two members of the Board shall be aldermen. Six members shall be citizens and residents of the City. 
(b)  For continuity of the Board, initial appointments were for staggered terms. Two citizen appointments shall be made annually hereafter on the third Tuesday of April, each for a 3-year term. The term of the aldermen shall be for one year. 
(c)  The Board members shall receive no compensation, except expenses, unless otherwise provided by ordinance. 
(2)  OFFICERS AND RULES. 
(a)  Officers. (Am. #04-O609) The Board shall choose from among its members a president and vice president annually in May of each year. A staff member of the Parks, Recreation and Forestry Department shall take minutes of all meetings of the Parks and Recreation Board. 
(b)  Rules. The Board shall adopt rules and regulations necessary to plan, promote, supervise and regulate all recreational activities to be offered by the City. 
(3)  DUTIES. The Parks and Recreation Board is empowered and directed: 
(a)  To aid and counsel the Director of Parks and Recreation. 
(b)  To establish recreation programs and set policy for park use. 
(c)  To govern, manage, control, improve and care for all public parks and parkways located within the corporate limits of the City, and to secure the quiet, orderly and suitable use and enjoyment thereof by the people. 
(d)  The Board shall study and develop forms of recreation in public parks, playgrounds and other property which may, from time to time, be placed under its direction by the Council. The Board may negotiate joint contracts with other municipalities subject to Council approval. 
(4)  QUORUM. A majority of the Board members shall constitute a quorum. The aldermen on the Board shall be entitled to vote on all matters and their attendance shall be counted for purposes of determining a quorum. 
(5)  OTHER PROVISIONS. See §21.01 of this Municipal Code. 
1.40 - BOARD OF REVIEW. 
(1)  APPOINTMENT. (Am. #00-0468) The Board of Review shall consist of 5 residents of the City, none of whom shall occupy any public office or be publicly employed. The members shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Council, for terms of 5 years and until their successors are appointed and qualified. Appointment shall be made before June 1 of each year. The first appointments shall be staggered so that one appointment is made each year. The Mayor may appoint an alternate member of the Board in addition to the 5 members above provided for, who shall act with full power only when a member of the Board refuses to vote because of conflict of interest, is absent, or if a person who is objecting to a valuation requests the removal of a member of the Board pursuant to the provisions of §70.47(6m), Wis. Stats. 
(2)  The Board of Review must include one voting member who, within 2 years of the Board's first meeting, has attended a training session under §73.03(54), Wis. Stats., and unless that member is the Mayor or the Mayor's designee. The City Clerk shall provide an affidavit to the Department of Revenue stating whether the requirement under this subsection has been fulfilled. (Am. #00-0468) 
(3)  DUTIES. The Board shall have the powers and duties prescribed in §70.47, Wis. Stats. 
(4)  CONFIDENTIALITY OF INFORMATION ABOUT INCOME AND EXPENSES. (Am. #99-0460) Whenever the Assessor, in the performance of the Assessor's duties, requests or obtains income and expense information pursuant to §70.47(7)(af), Wis. Stats., or any successor statute thereto, then such income and expense information that is provided to the Assessor shall be held by the Assessor on a confidential basis except, however, that the information may be released to and used by persons in the discharging of duties imposed by law, in the discharge of duties imposed by office (including, but not limited to, use by the Assessor in performance of official duties of the Assessor's office and used by the Board of Review in performance of its official duties) or pursuant to order of a court. Income and expense information provided to the Assessor under §70.47(7)(af), unless a court determines that it is inaccurate, is not, per §70.47(7)(af), subject to the right of inspection or copying under §19.35(1), Wis. Stats. 
1.41 - RESERVED. (Rep. #88-0198) 
1.42 - BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS . (Rep. & recr. #05-O638) 
(1)  ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP. 
(a)  The Board of Appeals shall consist of 5 members appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation of the Common Council, for terms of 3 years, except that of those first appointed, one shall serve for one year, 2 for 2 years, and 2 for 3 years, and shall be removable by the Mayor for cause upon written charges and after public hearing. The Mayor shall designate one of the members as chairperson. The Board may employ a secretary and other employees. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired terms of members whose terms become vacant. Each member shall serve until his/her successor is appointed and qualified. The Mayor shall appoint, for staggered terms of 3 years, 2 alternate members of such Board, in addition to the 5 members above provided for. Annually, the Mayor shall designate one of the alternate members as first alternate and the other as second alternate. The first alternate shall act, with full power, only when a member of the Board refuses to vote because of [conflict of] interest or when a member is absent. The second alternate shall so act only when the first alternate so refuses or is absent or when more than one member of the Board so refuses or is absent. The above provisions, with regard to removal and the filling of vacancies, shall apply to such alternates. 
(b)  If a quorum is present, the Board of Appeals may take action under this subsection by a majority vote of the members present. 
(2)  POWERS AND DUTIES; OTHER PROVISIONS. See §17.704(3) of this Municipal Code. (Am. #13-O841) 
1.43 - RESERVED. (Rep. #90-0245) 
1.44 - Bureau of Economic Development and Tourism Commission. (Am. #93-0305; #16-O901) 
(1)  HOW CONSTITUTED. 
(a)  The Bureau of Economic Development and Tourism Commission shall consist of 5 members: the Mayor or an Alderman, the Executive Director or a member of the Chamber of Commerce Board of Directors, a representative from the City's hotel and motel industry, a representative from the City's retail industry and a representative from the City's food and beverage industry. The member of the Chamber of Commerce shall be a resident of or have business interests within the City. (Am. #98-0426; #16-O901) 
(b)  All vacancies shall filled by appointed in April of each year by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the members of the municipality's governing body who are present when the vote is taken. (Am. #16-O901) 
(c)  The term of the Mayor/Alderman shall be for one year. The term of all other members shall be for staggered terms commencing on May 1 in the year in which the appointment is made. The initial appointments of the non-elected members shall be for the following terms: 2 for 3 years, one for 2 years and one for one year. Thereafter, the terms of non-elected members shall be 3 years and until their successors are appointed and qualified. Vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term. (Am. #16-O901) 
(d)  The Mayor or Alderman shall be chair of the Bureau and a member of the City administrative staff shall act as recording secretary for the Bureau. (Am. #16-O901) 
(e)  No compensation shall be paid to Bureau members for services as such, but they may be reimbursed for actual and necessary expenses incurred in performing duties outside the City if so authorized by the Bureau. 
(f)  The Bureau shall adopt rules for its own governance. (Am. #16-O901) 
(2)  DIRECTOR. The position of Director of the Economic Development Bureau is hereby established. The Director shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation of the Council. He/she shall be subject to the personnel policies and procedures of the City and be under the direction and supervision of the City Administrator. The Council shall fix the compensation of the Director. 
(3)  POWERS AND DUTIES. The Bureau shall: 
(a)  Have exclusive control of the expenditures of all monies donated or appropriated for the Bureau. 
(b)  After application and interviews, recommend to the Mayor, in rank order, eligible persons to fill the position of Director. 
(c)  After giving due consideration to the anticipated tax revenues collected under §3.08 of this Code (room tax), formulate and submit an annual budget pursuant to financial policies and procedures of the City. Funding for the Bureau shall be exclusively from room tax proceeds. The City shall not budget nor make payments in excess of the tax collected under §3.08 of this Code, less administrative expenses. No expenditures exceeding the budget approved by the Council shall be made without an appropriate fund transfer approved by the Council. (Am. #16-O901) 
(d)  Stimulate, promote, advertise and publicize tourism to the City and the resort and hotel community. 
(e)  Promote travel by visitors to the City's scenic, historic, natural, agricultural, educational and recreational attractions. (Am. #16-O901) 
(f)  Encourage all tourism related businesses to participate in available programs. (Am. #16-O901) 
(g)  Encourage and cooperate with communities, groups and individuals in the County and Lake Country area in pursuing the tourism promotion objectives of the department. (Am. #16-O901) 
(h)  Coordinate and stimulate the orderly and ecologically sound development of commercial tourist facilities throughout the City. (Am. #16-O901) 
(i)  Promote the growth of the tourism and recreation industry through research, planning and assistance. (Am. #16-O901) 
(j)  Support and assist the efforts of local business and industry, the Chamber of Commerce and other similar public and private agencies to foster expansion of existing commercial and industrial enterprises and initiate efforts to attract new enterprises, if within the economic development program plan of the City. (Cr. #16-O901) 
(k)  Identify for attention of the Council those significant business and industrial problems which may be relieved by City action. (Cr. #16-O901) 
(l)  Assist in the formulation and implementation of integrated economic and community development programs for the City. (Cr. #16-O901) 
(m)  Annually report to the City Administrator on the success of Bureau activities. (Cr. #16-O901) 
(4)  TRANSITION. The change in subsection (1)(a) relating to how the Bureau is constituted shall become effective with mayoral appointments in April of 1993. 
1.45 - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY . (Cr. #02-0530) 
(1)  [FINDINGS OF FACT.] The Common Council of the City of Oconomowoc specifically finds and declares that there is a need for blight elimination, slum clearance, urban renewal and community development programs and projects and housing projects in the City of Oconomowoc. 
(2)  CREATION. Pursuant to §66.1335, Wis. Stats., there is hereby created a Community Development Authority to be known as the "Community Development Authority of the City of Oconomowoc, Wisconsin." 
(3)  AUTHORIZATION. (Am. #04-0602) The Community Development Authority of the City of Oconomowoc, Wisconsin, is authorized to transact business and exercise any and all powers granted to a Community Development Authority under the Community Development Authority Law, as amended from time to time, for the purpose of carrying out blight elimination slum clearance, urban renewal programs and projects and housing projects; and authorized also to act as the agent of the City in planning and carrying out community development programs and activities approved by the Mayor and Common Council under the Federal Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, and as agent to perform all acts, except the development of the general plan of the City, which may be otherwise performed by the Plan Commission under §66.1105, §§66.1301 to 66.1329, §66.1331, §66.1333, or §66.1337, Wis. Stats. 
(4)  COMPOSITION AND PROCEDURES. 
(a)  [ Composition .] The Community Development Authority shall consist of 7 resident persons having sufficient ability and experience in the fields of urban renewal, community development and housing. These persons shall be known as commissioners of the Community Development Authority. 
(b)  Appointment . (Am. #05-O630) The commissioners shall be appointed by the Mayor, with confirmation by the Common Council, in April of each year. Terms shall commence on May 1 following appointment. Two of the commissioners shall be members of the Council and shall serve during their term of office as Council members. The first appointments of the 5 non-Council members shall be for the following terms: 2 for one year, and one each for the terms of 2, 3, and 4 years. Thereafter, the terms of non-Council members shall be 4 years and until their successors are appointed and qualified. Vacancies shall be filled for an unexpired term as provided for in this subsection. 
(c)  Chairperson . The Community Development Authority shall annually elect a chairperson and a vice-chairperson from among the commissioners. 
(d)  Compensation . The commissioners shall receive no compensation for their services but shall be entitled to reimbursement for their actual necessary expenses, including local travel expense included in the discharge of their duties. 
(e)  Meetings, Quorum and Bylaws . All meetings of the Community Development Authority shall be held in compliance with the provisions of the Open Meetings Law of the State of Wisconsin. Four commissioners shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of conducting its business and exercising its powers, and for all other purposes. Action may be taken by the Community Development Authority upon the affirmative vote of a majority of the commissioners present at any meeting. The Community Development Authority may adopt, and from time to time amend or repeal, such bylaws or other rules or regulations not inconsistent with the applicable laws of the State of Wisconsin and of this ordinance, as it deems necessary in the performance and function of its duties. The initial bylaws and subsequent amendments must also be approved by a majority vote of the Common Council. 
POLITICAL BOUNDARIES

(c)  Third Ward . All that part of Section 4 in Township 7, and all that part of Sections 28, 29, 32 and 33 in Township 8 North, all in Range 17 East, City of Oconomowoc, Waukesha County, Wisconsin, bounded and described as follows:

"16" and Wisconsin Avenue; thence S89°44'12"W along said centerline, 592.19 feet; thence S02°27'07"W along the East line of Lapham Street and its Northerly extension, 60 feet; thence S75°19'04"E along the Northerly line of said C.M.St.P.&P.R.R., 553.49 feet; thence Southerly along the East line and its Southerly extension of lands designated by Tax Key OCOC 0596-995-003, 1645 [feet] to a point on the centerline of Oconomowoc Parkway; thence Westerly and Southwesterly along said centerline, 2720 feet; thence N88°05'11"E along said South line, 1354.41 feet; thence S87°50'16"E along the South line of the Northwest 1/4 of Section 9, Town 7 North, Range 17 East, 179.35 feet to a point on the Northerly line of WEPCO lands; thence Southeasterly along said Northerly line, 450.64 feet along the arc of a curve whose center lies to the Northeast and whose radius is 1599.67 feet and whose chord bears S56°09'38"E, 449.15 feet; thence S64°13'51"E along said Northerly line, 919.69 feet to a point on the East line of the Northwest 1/4 of the Southwest 1/4 of said Section 9; thence Southeasterly along said Northerly line, 1330 feet more or less to a point that is 228.05 [feet] S08°07'35"W and 666.45 feet S00°14'08"E of the Northeast corner of the Northwest 1/4 of said Section 9; thence Northerly along the West line of the Briarwood subdivision, 885 feet; thence N00°54'02"W along the East line of the Northwest 1/4 of Section 9, 2541.84 feet to the point of beginning. 
The polling place for the Tenth Ward shall be the Oconomowoc Public Library, 200 South Street, Oconomowoc, Wisconsin 53066. 
(b)  Eleventh Ward . All that part of Sections 5 and 8 in Township 7 North, and all that part of Section 32 in Township 8 North, all in Range 17 East, City of Oconomowoc, Waukesha County, Wisconsin, bounded and described as follows: 
Beginning at the Northwest corner of the Northwest 1/4 of Section 8; thence Northerly and Easterly along the centerline of Concord Rd, 6260 feet; thence Northerly along the centerline of the Oconomowoc River, 33 feet;
