GENERAL 

13.01 - CITY UTILITIES. (Am. #00-0480) 
The waterworks systems, electric light and power distribution systems, and communications systems of the City are combined and are regulated by the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin. The City's wastewater treatment facility and systems are not combined with the electric, water, and communications utilities and are not regulated by the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin. The waterworks systems, electric light and power distribution systems, the wastewater treatment facility and systems, and the communications systems are enterprise funds and operated as the "City of Oconomowoc Utilities." 
13.02 - OPERATION. 
(1)  COMMON COUNCIL. 
(a)  Management . Management and control of the City Utilities shall be vested in the Common Council, acting as the Board of Public Works who shall have the powers and perform the functions of public utility commissions as prescribed by State Statutes. 
(b)  Rates and Regulations . (Am. #00-0480) The Common Council shall from time to time by adoption of appropriate ordinances or resolutions, classify the type of electric service available to customers, define the availability of electric, water and communications services, establish schedules of rates for electric, water and communications services, provide conditions for delivery of electric current, water service and communication services and promulgate such other rules and regulations it deems necessary and proper for the operation of the City Utilities, subject to control by the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin as provided by Wisconsin Statutes. 
(2)  SUPERVISION. The City Administrator shall supervise the operation of the Utilities under the general control and supervision of the Common Council (see §1.11(l)). 
(3)  UTILITY COMMITTEE. 
(a)  Appointment . As provided in § 2.07 of this Municipal Code, the Utility Committee shall consist of 3 aldermen appointed by the Mayor without Council approval at the first meeting of the Council in May of each year, but vacancies thereafter may be filled by the presiding officer of the Council. Any member of the Committee may be removed by resolution adopted by a vote of a majority of the members of the Council. The Mayor shall designate the chairman and secretary of the Committee. 
(b)  Authority of Utility Committee . The Utility Committee shall make recommendations to the Common Council concerning the operation of the City Utilities. 
(4)  OPERATIONS MANAGER. (Am. #10-O781) 
(a)  Appointment . As provided by §1.03(2) of this Municipal Code, the Mayor may appoint a Operations Manager, subject to confirmation to the Council. The Operations Manager shall receive such salary as the Council may direct. The Manager's term of employment is indefinite. 
(b)  Duties . The following duties and responsibilities in the operation of the City Utilities shall be performed by the Operations Manager who shall report to the City Administrator. 
1.  The Operations Manager shall be responsible for the day-to-day operations of the City Utilities, shall supervise the operation and interests of the City Utilities, and shall supervise the City Utilities' buildings, machinery and anything connected therewith. The Operations Manager shall be responsible for directing, coordinating and expediting the activities of the City Utilities. 
2.  The Operations Manager shall see that the bylaws, rules and regulations of the Council are executed. 
3.  The Operations Manager shall see that the conditions of all contracts by or with the City Utilities are faithfully complied with. 
4.  The Operations Manager shall make a quarterly and annual report of the condition and the operation of the City Utilities. 
5.  The Operations Manager shall appoint, after consultation with the City Administrator and subject to approval of the Common Council, all employees necessary to conduct the business of the City Utilities. Such employees shall hold their positions at the discretion of the Operations Manager. 
6.  The Operations Manager shall prepare the agenda for all committee meetings and shall distribute said agenda and such supporting data as may be required. 
7.  The Operations Manager shall perform such other duties in relation to the City Utilities as the City Administrator or the Common Council may direct. 
(5)  FINANCE DIRECTOR. (Am. #00-0480) 
Utility Duties . The following duties and responsibilities in the operation of the City Utilities shall be performed by the Finance Director, who shall report to the City Administrator: 
1.  The Finance Director shall see that the assessment of the water, sewer, electric, and communications charges are made, receipted for, and paid into the appropriate utility general fund. 
2.  The Finance Director shall keep all records pertaining to the management of the City Utilities in books provided for that purpose. Such records shall show names of all consumers, description of premises supplied, uses to which water supply is put, rate of tariff, collections made and such other items as the Council may require. 
3.  The Finance Director shall examine all accounts and claims, approve the same if correct and submit them to the Finance Committee. 
4.  The Finance Director shall develop budgeting procedures and supervise in the preparation of an annual budget for the City Utilities. The Operations Manager, in cooperation with the Finance Director, shall be responsible for coordinating financial and economic data for the City Utilities' long-range plan. (Am. #10-O781) 
13.03 - SERVICE TERRITORY. 
(1)  POLICY. As a matter of policy, the service territory of the City Utilities should be at least coextensive with the City limits, and those customers and residents within the City should, as a condition of being within the City, obtain all their governmental services from the City. Other rate payers and taxpayers within the City fund these services for the benefit of all City residents. City Residents and customers should not be able to pick and choose which municipal services they wish to support and which they wish to obtain elsewhere. 
(2)  ELECTRIC AND WATER SERVICE TERRITORY; RESIDENTS REQUIREMENT. The City Utilities shall serve all persons within the City limits, except as may be modified pursuant to subsection (5) hereof. All persons residing within the City limits, and all business entities located within the City limits, are hereby required to obtain their electric and water service from the City Utilities. This requirement does not apply to any generating or electricity producing facilities owned by the resident or customer. 
(3)  AUTHORITY. This section was adopted pursuant to the Council's authority under §§ 62.11(5), 66.069(2), 196.495, 196.58 and Ch. 197, Wis. Stats. In addition, to the extent issues related to the electric and water utility operations are within the City's power under Art. XI, §3 of the Wisconsin Constitution, the City is utilizing its authority under that provision and §66.01, Wis. Stats., to adopt this section. 
(4)  SERVICE REQUIREMENT A CONDITION OF ANNEXATION. Any person or landowner petitioning the City for annexation of property to the City shall agree, as a condition of annexation, that any electric power and water service requirements for the property will, upon annexation, be obtained from the City Utilities. The landowner will cooperate in all ways with the City to effect this requirement. 
(5)  WAIVER. The Council may agree to release a customer from these requirements on a temporary basis where special circumstances are shown but may, at any time thereafter, advise the customer that the requirements will be enforced. 
(6)  SEVERABILITY. Each subsection of this section is severable, and the failure or invalidity of one subsection shall not affect the validity of the remaining subsections. 
13.04 - USE OF UTILITY INCOME. 
The income of the City Utilities shall be used to meet operation, maintenance, depreciation, interest, and debt service fund requirements; local and school tax equivalents; additions and improvements; and other necessary disbursements or indebtedness. Income in excess of these requirements may be used to purchase and hold interest bearing bonds, issued for the acquisition of the City Utilities, or bonds issued by the United States or any municipal corporation of this State. 
13.05 - ASSESSMENTS. 
(1)  SPECIAL ASSESSMENT PROCEDURE. See §8.12 of this Municipal Code. 
(2)  SECTION 66.08, WIS. STATS., ADOPTED. In addition to those special assessment procedures adopted by the Council in §8.12 of this Municipal Code, the Council may elect to levy special assessments pertaining to electric facilities as provided in this section. Whenever the City Utilities shall construct or acquire by gift, purchase or otherwise a distribution system or a production or generating plant for the furnishing of electric service to the City or its inhabitants or shall make any extensions thereto, the City may assess the whole or any part of the cost thereof to the property benefited thereby, whether abutting or not, in the same manner as is provided for the assessment of benefits under §66.60 Wis. Stats. 
13.06 - COLLECTION OF DELINQUENT WATER AND ELECTRIC CHARGES. (Rep. & recr. #96-0377) 
(1)  AUTHORITY. The Common council of the City of Oconomowoc adopts §§66.069(1)(b) and 66.069(1)(bn), Wis. Stats., by reference. 
(2)  PROCEDURE. 
(a)  The Operations Manager shall inform the City Treasurer before October 15 of each year of all lots or parcels for which water and/or electric charges are still owed for service supplied in the year preceding October 1. (Am. #10-O781) 
(b)  On October 15 in each year, notice shall be given by the Water and/or Electric Utility to the owner or occupant of all lots or parcels of real estate to which utility service has been furnished prior to October 1 and payment for which is owing and in arrears at the time of giving such notice. The Water and/or Electric Utility shall furnish the City Treasurer with a list of all such lots or parcels of real estate and the notice shall be given by the City Treasurer. Such notice shall be in writing and shall state the amount of such arrears, including any penalty assessed pursuant to the rules of the Water and/or Electric Utility, that unless the delinquent account is paid by November 1 thereafter, a penalty of 10 percent of the amount of such arrears will be added thereto; and that unless such arrears with any such added penalty, shall be paid by November 15 thereafter, the same will be levied as a tax against the lot or parcel of real estate to which utility service was furnished and for which payment is delinquent. Such notice may be served by delivery to either such owner or occupant personally or by letter addressed to such owner or occupant at the post office addresses of such lot or parcel of real estate. On November 16 the City Treasurer shall certify and file with the Clerk a list of all lots or parcels of real estate, giving the legal descriptions thereof, to the owners or occupants of which notice of arrears in payment were given as above specified and which arrears still remain unpaid, and stating the amount of such arrears together with the added penalty thereon as herein provided. 
(3)  LIEN FOR DELINQUENT CHARGES. Each delinquent amount, including penalty, shall thereupon become a lien upon the lot or parcel of real estate to which the utility service was furnished and payment for which is delinquent, and the City Clerk shall insert the same as a tax against such lot or parcel of real estate. All proceedings in relation to the collection of general property taxes and to the return and sale of property for delinquent taxes shall apply to said delinquent tax if the same is not paid within the time required by law for payment of taxes upon real estate. 
(4)  WATER OR ELECTRIC UTILITY SERVICE TO RENTAL DWELLING UNITS. 
(a)  This section applies only if all of the following conditions are met: 
1.  Water and Electric Utility service is provided to a rental dwelling unit. 
2.  The owner of the rental dwelling unit notifies the Utility in writing of the name and address of the owner. 
3.  The owner of the rental dwelling unit notifies the Utility in writing of the name and address of the tenant who is responsible for payment of the utility charges. 
4.  If requested by the Utility, the owner of the rental dwelling unit provides the Utility with a copy of the rental or lease agreement in which the tenant assumes responsibility for the payment of the utility charges. 
(b)  The Water or Electric Utility shall comply with at least one of the following methods of notification: 
1.  The Water or Electric Utility shall send bills for water or electric service to a customer who is a tenant in the tenant's own name. 
Upon notification to a customer who is a tenant that charges for water or electric service provided by the Utility to the customer are past due for more than one billing cycle, the Utility shall also serve a copy of the notice on the owner of the rental dwelling unit in the manner provided in §801.14(2), Wis. Stats. If a customer who is a tenant vacates the rental dwelling unit and the owner of the rental dwelling unit provides the public utility, no later than 21 days after the date on which the tenant vacates the rental dwelling unit in the manner set forth below. 
2.  The Water or Electric Utility shall serve notice of the past due charges on the owner of the rental dwelling unit within 14 days of the date on which the tenant's charges become past due. The public utility shall serve notice on the owner of the rental dwelling unit in the manner provided in §801.14(2), Wis. Stats. 
13.07 - UTILITIES SUBJECT TO PSCW JURISDICTION. 
(1)  FILING OF SCHEDULES. (Am. #00-0480) In accordance with §196.19, Wis. Stats., the City Utilities shall file with the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin all schedules showing the rates, charges, rules and regulations governing the electric, water, and communications services provided by the City Utilities. 
(2)  CONFLICTS. In case of a conflict between this Municipal Code and the schedules on file with the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin, the schedules shall control. 
(3)  INFORMATION AVAILABLE TO CUSTOMERS. (Am. #10-O781) The Operations Manager shall have available in the office of the City Utilities copies of the Utilities' rates and rules. The rates and rules shall be available for customer inspection. 
13.075 - CAPITAL COST RECOVERY CHARGES . (Cr. #06-O677) 
(1)  DEFINED. A charge levied on new users within certain designated service areas to reimburse the Developer that initially financed the improvements for the cost of capital improvements that benefit all of the properties in the designated service area. 
(2)  ESTABLISHED. Capital cost recovery charges shall be collected by the City from properties that benefit from, but were not initially required to finance, and pay a special assessment for or otherwise contribute to the cost of, capital improvements within certain designated service areas. Capital cost recovery charges are hereby established for properties that meet all of the following criteria: 
(a)  Are located within an area benefited by a water system or sanitary sewer improvement for which the City has levied special assessments. 
(b)  Were located outside of the City at the time when the special assessments were levied. 
(c)  Capital costs for the improvements were allocated to the property in the engineer's report. 
(3)  AMOUNT OF CAPITAL COST RECOVERY CHARGES. The amount of the charge shall be the amount allocated to each property, plus any interest, as specified in the engineer's report. 
(4)  COLLECTION OF CAPITAL COST RECOVERY CHARGES. Capital cost recovery charges calculated and due pursuant to this section shall be collected by the City prior to connection to the sanitary sewer or water system. 
(5)  DISPOSITION OF CAPITAL COST RECOVERY CHARGES. All charges collected pursuant to this section shall be deposited in an appropriate segregated fund. The City shall use all charges collected pursuant to this section to reimburse the developer that initially financed the improvements for which the charges are to be collected within 30 days of receipt. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 06-O677, adopted Nov. 21, 2006, enacted provisions creating a new §13.08. Inasmuch as there already exists such a section, said provisions have been redesigated as §13.075 to avoid duplication of numbers. 
ELECTRIC SERVICE 

13.08 - RULES, RATES AND REGULATIONS. 
All persons now receiving electrical service from the City Utilities or who may hereafter make application therefor shall be considered as having agreed to be bound by all rules and regulations as filed with the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin. A customer's violation of any such rules shall constitute a violation of this section and shall be punishable as provided in §25.04 of this Municipal Code. 
13.09 - ADOPTION OF PSC 113. 
The following sections of Ch. PSC 113, Wis. Adm. Code, are adopted by reference and made a part of these rules as if set forth in full.

13.10 - APPLICATION FOR ELECTRICAL SERVICE. 
(1)  WRITTEN APPLICATION. Application for electrical service shall be made by the owner of the premises, or the occupant thereof with written consent of the owner, in writing on a form furnished by the City Utilities. The application shall contain a street address and/or legal description of the property to be served, the use to be made of service and such other information as the Utilities may require. 
(2)  SITE PLAN LAYOUT. If the request for electrical service is larger than 200 amp., the applicant shall submit, in addition to a copy of the building permit, a site plan layout of the electrical underground services required and the location of the transformer. No permit shall be issued for multiple-family dwellings, stores, manufacturing plants or shopping centers unless such material is submitted with the application and approved. 
(3)  REFUSAL OF SERVICE. The City Utilities may refuse electrical services if the permittee fails to install the electrical service connection in accordance with the approved plans. 
13.11 - ELECTRICAL SERVICE. 
(1)  METERS. (Am. #10-O781) Electric meters shall be furnished by the City Utilities and installed under the direction of the Operations Manager. Not more than one customer may receive electricity through one meter, unless each pays the minimum rate if the meter registers less than that amount. No unauthorized person shall tamper with an electric meter. 
(2)  RIGHT OF ENTRY TO INSPECT METER. Employees of the City Utilities shall have access to the consumer's premises at all reasonable hours to inspect the meter and exchange the same, if necessary. 
(3)  RESPONSIBILITY OF CONSUMER. The consumer of electricity shall be responsible for all electricity used on the consumer's premises until notice to the contrary is given at the office of the City Utilities. 
(4)  NOTIFICATION OF ALTERATION, ETC. The consumer shall notify the City Utilities of all alterations, additions and repairs on wires on the consumer's premises, and such work shall be done in accordance with Utilities' PSC rate file, the Rules and Regulations of the Utilities and to the satisfaction of the Building Inspector. 
(5)  ALTERATIONS AND REPAIRS. All alterations and repairs to wires and fixtures on consumer's premises shall be at the expense of the consumer, and the City Utilities may shut off electricity until all necessary repairs are made. 
(6)  LIABILITY RESTRICTED. The City Utilities shall not be liable for failure to furnish electricity if such failure is caused by accidents, strikes or other causes beyond the control of the Utilities. 
(7)  ELECTRIC BILLS. Electric bills will be rendered monthly. 
(8)  RECONNECTION OF SERVICE. (Am. #10-O781) If the Utility disconnects any electrical service for a lawful permitted reason, such service shall not be reconnected except by order of the Operations Manager and on payment of necessary fee and such other terms as the City may determine. 
(9)  DISCONTINUING SERVICE. (Am. #10-O781) Any person desiring to discontinue the use of electricity shall give notice thereof in writing to the Operations Manager. 
(10)  COMPLIANCE WITH ELECTRIC UTILITY STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS. (Cr. #06-O667) All contractors proposing to install or revise electric service on property within the City of Oconomowoc shall comply with the Public Service Commission rules set forth in §13.09 of the Municipal Code and shall comply with local standards and specifications contained in book form and available for inspection at the Utility office. The standards and specifications book contains construction or installation standards and specifications for electric infrastructure. Electric Utility staff may periodically add to or revise the standards and specifications. Any electric service construction or installation which violates the standards and specifications is subject to removal or disconnection. 
13.12 - CONSEQUENCES OF FAILING TO PAY ELECTRIC CHARGES. 
(1)  DISCONNECTION. If a customer fails to pay a delinquent electric bill, the City Utilities may disconnect the customer's electric service, refuse further service and take any other steps provided for in PSC 113, Wis. Adm. Code. Any disconnection shall be in compliance with PSC 113.1324, Wis. Adm. Code, pertaining to cold weather disconnections. 
(2)  DELINQUENT BILLS PLACED ON PROPERTY TAX ROLLS. The City Utilities may collect overdue bills by placing the bills on the property tax as provided in §§66.069 and 66.076 Wis. Stats., and §13.06 of this Municipal Code. 
13.13 - INTERFERENCE WITH ELECTRICAL UTILITY EQUIPMENT. 
No customer shall destroy, injure or interfere with any apparatus or appliance owned by the City Utilities and used to provide electric service. A customer's violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in §25.04 of this Municipal Code. 
13.14 - DEFACING UTILITY POLES. 
(1)  No person shall attach to any pole supporting electric wires (i.e. telegraph, telephone or electric light poles) any advertisement or notice, nor shall any person drive or insert any nails, brads, screws or any other metal substance into any such poles. 
(2)  This section shall not apply to the attaching of legal notices or notices given by any officer of the city, county, state or school district. 
(3)  No person shall attach or secure personal property to any pole supporting electric wires (i.e., telegraph, telephone or electric light poles), street light poles, traffic signal poles or flashing warning light poles. To attach or secure includes, but is not limited to, the use of chains or cables with or without padlocks. The Police Department shall cause to be removed any personal property attached or secured to any of the aforementioned public poles. A notice shall be prepared which shall describe the personal property and order its removal, stating that if the personal property is not permanently removed or the violation is not corrected within 48 hours, the personal property shall be removed by the Police Department. The notice shall be attached to the personal property. Any personal property removed by the Police Department pursuant to the provisions of this section shall become the property of the City and may be disposed of in any manner deemed appropriate by the City. The Police Department shall store the personal property for not less than 10 days before disposal. (Cr. #00-0473) 
WATER 

13.15 - RULES, RATES AND REGULATIONS. 
All persons now receiving a water supply from the City Utilities or who may hereafter apply to receive water from the City Utilities shall be considered as having agreed to be bound by all rules and regulations filed with the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin. A customer's violation of any such rules shall constitute a violation of this section and shall be punishable as provided in §25.04 of this Municipal Code. 
13.16 - ADOPTION OF PSC 185. (Am. #00-0473) 
The following provisions of Ch. PSC 185, Wis. Adm. Code, and all other future amendments, are adopted by reference and made a part of these rules as if set forth in full. 
Section 185.11 Authorization for Application of Rules 185.12 Definitions 185.13 General Requirements 185.15 Free or Discriminatory Service Prohibited 185.16 Protection of Utility Facilities 185.17 Interference with Public Service Structures 185.18 Location of Records 185.19 Retention of Records 185.21 Schedules to be Filed with the Commission 185.22 Information Available to Customers 185.31 Metered Service 185.32 Metered Readings and Billing Periods 185.33 Billings 185.35 Adjustment of Bills 185.36 Deposits 185.361 Deposits for Nonresidential Service 185.37 Disconnection and Refusal of Service 185.38 Deferred Payment Agreement 185.39 Dispute Procedures 185.41 Employees Authorized to Enter Customers' Premises 185.42 Customer Complaints 185.43 Construction Records 185.44 Records and Reports of Service Interruptions 185.45 Pumpage Records 185.46 Metering Equipment Records 185.47 Other Records 185.51 Requirement for Good Engineering Practice 185.52 Construction Standards 185.53 Metering Configuration 185.61 Meters 185.65 Accuracy Requirements for Customer Meters 185.71 Meter Testing Facilities and Equipment 185.72 Calibration of Meter Testing Equipment 185.73 Testing of Customer Meters 185.74 Test Flows 185.75 Required Tests of Customer Meters 185.751 Alternate Sample-testing Plan for "Before Use" Test for 3/4 and One Inch Meters 185.76 Periodic Tests 185.761 Alternative Sample-Testing Plan for In-Use Meters 185.77 Complaint Tests 185.78 Referee Tests 185.79 Testing of Metering Installations Having Remote Registers 185.795 Jumpering Meter Settings 185.81 Quality of Water 185.815 Adequacy of Water Supply 185.82 Pressure Standards 185.83 Station Meters 185.84 Emergency Operation 185.85 System Losses 185.86 Flushing Mains 185.87 Operation of Distribution System Valves and Hydrants 185.88 Interruptions of Service 185.89 Thawing Frozen Services  
13.17 - EXTENSION OF WATER MAINS AND LATERALS. 
(1)  SUBDIVISIONS. Pursuant to §18.08(3) of this Municipal Code, subdividers are responsible for installing and paying for the extension of water supply to a subdivision. The installation of the water extension must be approved as provided for in §18.08(3). 
(2)  OTHER EXTENSIONS; SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS. For other extensions of water mains and laterals, the extensions shall be paid for as determined by the City. The City may choose to use the special assessment procedure provided for in §§8.12 and 13.05 of this Municipal Code to pay for the extensions. 
(3)  CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS. The installation of all water mains and laterals shall conform to the specifications for water utility construction as determined by the City Utilities. The water construction specifications are on file in the City Utilities office. The specifications of the City Utilities shall be no less strict than the specifications set forth in Chs. ILHR 82 and 84, NR 811, and PSC 185, Wis. Adm. Code. 
(4)  CONNECTIONS AND SERVICE FOR ATTACHED TOWN OF SUMMIT PROPERTIES. (Cr. #10-O768) The installation of all water mains and laterals and the connection and service to be provided to Town of Summit properties attached to the City shall be as provided in the following paragraphs. Section 13.19 relating to compulsory connection to water system shall be interpreted consistent with this §13.17(4). 
(a)  Individual Developed Properties . Connection to the City water system will be required for all properties upon private well failure. Exception: Replacement of private wells with replacement wells will be permitted if City water is not available and state and/or county regulations allow replacement. Once City water is available, connection will be required within 12 years. Interest will be charged on deferred assessments. 
(b)  Riverline Subdivision . City water is currently available to properties on the north portion of this subdivision. Properties can request approval to connect to existing water mains at any time. City water to the currently unserved area of this subdivision will become available when sewer is installed or when a majority of the properties petition for City water. 
Connection can be deferred for up to 12 years from the date water becomes available to the subdivision. Assessment for water mains can be deferred for up to 12 years from the date water becomes available or connection to main, whichever occurs first. Interest will be charged on deferred assessments. 
(c)  Paganica Court Subdivision. (Cr. #15-O872) This subsection applies to all properties, improved and unimproved, which currently consists of 5 single-family residential lots on Paganica Court extending from Silver Lake Street to its terminus. City water to this subdivision will become available when and if sewer is installed or when a majority of the properties petition for City water. When and if City water becomes available, connection to the City water system can be deferred for up to 12 years from the date water becomes available to the subdivision. Assessment for water mains can be deferred for up to 12 years from the date water becomes available or connection to main, whichever occurs first. With regard to the 5 lots in this subdivision, or any newly-created lots, private wells shall be authorized until public water becomes available. 
(d)  Vacant or Undeveloped Land . (Am. #15-O872) Development or improvement of vacant land will be permitted only when water and sewer are available to the land being improved. 
(e)  Temporary Connection to City Water . (Am. #15-O872) If a residential or commercial well fails and a temporary connection can be made to an existing water main, this connection will be permitted with the following conditions: 
1.  Property owner agrees to pay all costs of temporary connection and acquires all necessary easements; 
2.  Property owner agrees to install temporary service per City specifications; 
3.  Property owner agrees to connect to permanent main when it becomes available; 
4.  Property owner agrees to abandon temporary service when the City installs the permanent main; and 
5.  Property owner agrees to pay the assessment for the permanent main when it is installed. 
(f)  Private Well Abandonment . (Am. #15-O872) 
1.  Property owner must abandon private well pursuant to City and Waukesha County regulations upon connection. 
2.  Commercial users of high capacity wells will be permitted to continue using such wells upon issuance of a permit by the City Water Utility. 
13.18 - WATER MAIN SIZE. 
(1)  RESIDENTIAL SUBDIVISIONS . Water main pipe size for residential subdivisions as required in §18.08(3) of this Municipal Code shall not be less than 8 inches in size. 
(2)  COMMERCIAL, INDUSTRIAL OR INSTITUTIONAL USERS. Water main pipe size for commercial, industrial or institutional use shall not be less than 12 inches in size. 
13.19 - COMPULSORY CONNECTION TO WATER SYSTEM . (Am. #10-O768) 
The owner of any public, commercial, mercantile or business building, or any building used for human habitation situated in the City and adjacent to a water main, is required to connect such buildings to the water supply as provided for in §§11.07 and 13.03 of this Municipal Code. This requirement shall be interpreted consistent with the provisions of §13.17(4) with regard to Town of Summit properties attached to the City. 
13.20 - APPLICATION FOR WATER SERVICE. 
(1)  WRITTEN APPLICATION. Application for water service or for any extension or alteration of an existing service shall be made in writing by the owner of the property, or an authorized agent therefor, on a form furnished by the City Utilities. The application will contain the legal description and/or street address of the property to be served, the name of the owner, the exact use to be made of the service, and the size of the supply pipe and meter desired. The City Utilities may withhold approval of any application if full information of the purpose of the water supply is not clearly indicated by the applicant. 
(2)  APPROVAL OF APPLICATION. Upon approval of an application, the Building Inspector shall issue a permit to the licensed plumber selected by the applicant which authorizes the plumber to do the work. A permit shall be issued for each service connection, for each building, residence, or business place, and for each branch connection, when more than one connection is made by one service pipe. 
(3)  LICENSED PLUMBER. (Am. #10-O781) No person whose premises is to be supplied with water shall employ any person other than a licensed plumber or fitter named in the permit to make the connection or attachment. If a licensed plumber is not used, the Operations Manager may withhold water service to the premises. 
(4)  LIMITATION ON USE OF WATER. No person shall use or permit any water to be used for any purpose not designated in the permit. 
(5)  DEPOSITS AND GUARANTEED CONTRACTS. Prior to providing service, the City Utilities may under certain circumstances first require a deposit from the customer, or a guaranteed contract. Provisions governing deposits may be found in PSC 185, Wis. Adm. Code. A copy of PSC 185 may be obtained from the City Utilities office. 
(6)  OTHER RULES. The Water Utility Operating Rules and Regulations filed with the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin also govern applications for service. These rules, as part of City Utility's rate file, include provisions on conditions of service, options for service to a multi-unit dwelling, and service to a lot or parcel. A copy of these rules may be obtained from the City Utilities office. 
13.21 - INSTALLATION OF WATER SERVICE. 
(1)  INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS. The installation of all new, extended, or altered water services shall conform to the requirements and specifications for water construction as determined by the City Utilities. The water construction specifications and installation requirements are on file in the City Utilities office. The specifications of the City Utilities shall be no less strict than the specifications set forth in Chs. ILHR 82 and 84, NR 811 and PSC 185, Wis. Adm. Code. 
(2)  NO PLASTIC PIPES. No plastic pipe may be used in the installation of individual service laterals between the water main and the stop box. The City Utilities are required to thaw the service laterals in the event of freezing. Plastic pipes cannot be thawed with heat, and thawing by reversing the flow of hot water would violate the regulations on cross-connections. 
(3)  REFUSAL OF SERVICE. (Am. #10-O781) The Operations Manager may refuse water service to a permittee if such permittee fails to install the water service connection in accordance with the approved plans. 
(4)  TURNING ON WATER. A consumer's water cannot be turned on for a consumer except by a duly authorized employee of the Utilities. 
13.22 - RESPONSIBILITY FOR CARE OF PIPES. 
(1)  PROPERTY OWNER'S RESPONSIBILITY. Any person being supplied water from the City Utilities shall at his or her expense maintain the service pipes from the curb stop to the point of use and all fixtures connected to the service pipes in good repair and protected from frost. The alignment and proper maintenance of the stop box remains the responsibility of the proper owner. 
(2)  CONSEQUENCES OF FAILURE TO REPAIR. If an owner fails to repair a leaking or broken service pipe from curb stop to point of metering or use within such time as may appear reasonable to the City Utilities, the Utilities will shut off the water after notification has been given to the owner by the Utilities. The water will not be turned on again until the repairs have been completed. 
(3)  UTILITY'S RESPONSIBILITY. The service pipe from the main, to and through the curb stop, will be maintained and kept in repair and when worn out, replaced at the expense of the City Utilities. 
(4)  SHUTTING OFF WATER DURING REPAIRS. The City Utilities reserve the right to shut off the water in the mains temporarily to make repairs, alterations or additions to the plant or system. No rebate will be allowed to consumers for such temporary suspension of water supply. 
(5)  LIMITATION ON CLAIMS. No claim shall be made against the City because of (1) the breakage of any main pipe, service pipe, cock, or any equipment or machinery, or (2) any interruption of supply because of stoppage for necessary repairs. 
13.23 - WATER METERS. 
(1)  CONNECTION. All water service shall be connected with a meter furnished by the City. The meters shall be installed by the City Utilities, or at the Utilities' option an authorized licensed plumber, in accordance with the requirements established by the City Utilities. The owner of the premises at his or her expense must provide a suitable location and proper connections for a meter, in accordance with the requirements established by the City Utilities. See also the Water Utility Operating Rules filed with the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin. A copy of these rules may be obtained from the City Utilities office. 
(2)  MAINTENANCE. Meters will be repaired by the City Utilities. The cost of repairs caused by ordinary wear and tear will be borne by the City Utilities. The cost of repairs caused by damage to a meter resulting from the carelessness or negligence of the owner of the premises, the owner's agent, or tenant shall be paid for by the consumer or the owner of the premises. 
(3)  ACCESS TO METERS. (Am. #10-O781) The Operations Manager or a duly authorized person shall be given access to the premises and buildings for the purpose of examining or repairing any meter or connection. Meters shall be left in the condition and manner as set and shall not be interfered with. 
13.24 - WATER CHARGES. 
(1)  RATES. The current rates for service are set forth in the Water Utility Rate File which is on file with the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin. 
(2)  CALCULATION OF BILLS. Water charges are calculated as set forth in PSC 185, Wis. Adm. Code. PSC 185 also provides the procedure for reading meters, estimating charges, and adjusting erroneous charges. A copy of PSC 185 may be obtained from the City Utilities office. 
(3)  BILLING. All water charges shall be billed and paid for as set forth in the Water Utility Rate File. Currently, water charges are billed monthly, and if the water charges are not paid within 20 days of billing, interest or penalties shall be added to the bill. A copy of the current rate file may be obtained from the City Utilities office. 
(4)  MISCELLANEOUS CHARGES. Other charges, such as installation charges, reconnection charges, hydrant charges, and meter charges, are as set forth in the current Water Utility Rate File which is on file with the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin. A copy of the current rate file may be obtained from the City Utilities office. 
13.25 - CONSEQUENCES OF FAILING TO PAY WATER CHARGES. 
(1)  DISCONNECTION. If a customer fails to pay water charges, the City Utilities may disconnect the customer's water service, refuse further service and take the other steps provided for in PSC 185, Wis. Adm. Code. 
(2)  DELINQUENT BILLS PLACED ON PROPERTY TAX ROLLS. The City Utilities may collect overdue bills by placing the bills on the property tax as provided in §66.069, Wis. Stats., and §13.06 of this Municipal Code. 
13.26 - PROTECTIVE DEVICES. 
The owner or occupant of every premises receiving water supply shall apply and maintain suitable means of protection of the premise's water supply, and all appliances thereof, against damage arising in any manner from the use of the water supply, variation of water pressure, or any interruption of water supply. For specific rules regarding protective devices, including but not limited to relief valves, air chambers and pressure safety cutout devices, see the Water Utility Operating Rules filed with the Public Service Commission of Wisconsin. A copy of these rules may be obtained from the City Utilities office. 
13.27 - TERMINATION OF SERVICE. 
(1)  VACATION OF PREMISES. When premises are to be vacated, the City Utilities shall be notified, in writing, at least 3 working days prior to vacation, so that it may remove the meter and shut off the water supply at the curb valve. The owner of the premises shall be liable for water used and any damage to the property of the City Utilities by reason of failure to notify the City Utilities of the vacancy. 
(2)  CAPPING REQUIRED. If any building is moved, razed or otherwise altered so as to expose or leave abandoned water utility terminals, such terminals shall be appropriately capped in accordance with the standards established by the City Utilities. All such capping shall be done at the expense of the owner of the premises or person responsible therefor. 
13.28 - BONDING OF AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL. 
The Council may authorize persons to fulfill certain obligations of the City Utilities. Any person authorized by the Council shall at the time of receiving the appointment execute and deliver to the City Clerk a bond with one or more sureties approved by the Council in the amount set by the City, conditioned that he or she will indemnify and save harmless the City of and from all damages caused by any careless or improper work done by him or her. 
13.29 - SERVICE BEYOND CITY LIMITS. 
(1)  EXTENSIONS PROHIBITED. Except as otherwise provided by the Common Council, no water connection shall be extended to property outside the current City limits, as reflected in the current City map, which is incorporated herein by reference. 
(2)  EXCEPTIONS. This section shall not interfere with or abrogate the rights of any present users of record connected to the municipal water services outside the City limits, as reflected in the modified City map, which is incorporated herein by reference and on file with the City Clerk. 
(3)  RESERVED. (Rep. #00-0473) 
13.30 - CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL. 
(1)  DEFINED. A cross-connection shall be defined as any physical connection or arrangement between 2 otherwise separate systems, one of which contains potable water from the City water system and the other, water from a private source, water of unknown or questionable safety or steam, gases or chemicals, whereby there may be a flow from one system to the other, the direction of flow depending on the pressure differential between the 2 systems. 
(2)  CROSS-CONNECTION PROHIBITED. No person shall establish or maintain or permit to be established or maintained any cross-connection. No interconnection shall be established whereby potable water from a private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply of the City may enter the supply or distribution system of the City, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the City Utilities and by the State DNR in accordance with NR 811.09(2), Wis. Adm. Code. 
(3)  INSPECTIONS. The City Utilities shall cause inspections to be made of all properties served by the public water system where cross-connections with the public water system is deemed possible. The frequency of inspections and reinspections based on potential health hazards involved shall be as established by the City and as approved by the State DNR. 
(4)  RIGHT OF ENTRY. Upon presentation of credentials, the representative of the City Utilities shall have the right to request entry at any reasonable time to examine any property served by a connection to the public water system of the City for cross-connections. If entry is refused, such representative shall obtain a special inspection warrant under §66.122, Wis. Stats. On request the owner, lessee or occupant of any property so served shall furnish to the inspection agency any pertinent information regarding the piping system on such property. 
(5)  DISCONTINUANCE. The City Utilities is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue water service to any property wherein any connection in violation of this section exists, and to take such other precautionary measures deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water system. Water service shall be discontinued only after reasonable notice and opportunity for hearing under Ch. 68 Wis. Stats., except as provided in subsection (6). Water service to such property shall not be restored until the cross-connection has been eliminated in compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(6)  EMERGENCY DISCONTINUANCE. If it is determined by the City Utilities that a cross-connection or an emergency endangers public health, safety or welfare and requires immediate action and a written finding to that effect is filed with the City Clerk and delivered to the customer's premises, service may be immediately discontinued. The customer shall have an opportunity for hearing under Ch. 68, Wis. Stats., within 10 days of such emergency discontinuance. 
(7)  STATE CODE. The City adopts by reference the State Plumbing Code, Chs. ILHR 82 and 84, Wis. Adm. Code. This section does not supersede the State Plumbing Code and the City's Plumbing Code, but is supplementary to them. 
13.31 - PRIVATE WELL ABANDONMENT . (Am. #04-O612) 
(1)  PURPOSE. The purpose of this section is to prevent unused and/or improperly constructed wells from serving as a passage for contaminated surface or near surface waters or other materials to reach the usable groundwater. These wells must be properly abandoned and sealed. 
(2)  COVERAGE. All private wells locate on any premises which is served by the public water system of the City shall be properly abandoned. Only those wells for which a well operation permit has been granted by the Water Utility may be exempted from this requirement, subject to conditions, maintenance and operation. 
(3)  WELL OPERATION PERMITS. A permit may be granted to a well owner to operate a well for a period not to exceed 5 years if the following requirements are met: 
(a)  Application shall be made on forms provided by the City Engineer and shall be renewed every 5 years. 
(b)  The well and pump installation meet the requirements of Ch. NR 812, Wis. Adm. Code, and a well constructor's report is on file with the state. 
(c)  The well has a history of producing safe water and presently produces bacteriologically safe water as evidenced by 2 samplings 2 weeks apart. 
(d)  The proposed use of the well can be justified as being necessary in addition to water provided by the public water system. 
(e)  No physical condition shall exist between the piping of the public water system and the private well. 
(4)  METHODS. Wells to be abandoned shall be abandoned according to the procedures outlined in Ch. NR 812, Wis. Adm. Code. The pump and piping must be removed and the well checked for obstructions prior to plugging. Any obstruction or liner must be removed. 
(5)  REPORTS AND INSPECTION. A well abandonment report must be submitted by the well owner to the City Engineer and Water Utility on forms provided by the agency, available in the office of the City Engineer. The report shall be submitted immediately upon completion of the well abandonment, which must be observed by a representative of the City. 
(6)  PENALTY. Any well owner violating any provision of this section shall upon conviction be subject to a forfeiture as provided in §25.04 of the Municipal Code. Each 24-hour period during which a violation exists shall constitute a separate offense. 
13.32 - WELLHEAD PROTECTION. 
The City has restricted groundwater recharge areas as to uses permitted in said areas. See §17.115 of this Municipal Code for these wellhead protection provisions. (Am. #13-O841) 
13.33 - PRIVATE WELL MAINTENANCE . (Cr. #04-O612) 
All maintenance on a private well must be completed and/or inspected by an individual licensed under Ch. NR 146, Wis. Adm. Code. 
SEWER USER REGULATIONS 

13.45 - CREATION. 
The Common Council, pursuant to the provisions of §66.067, Wis. Stats., does hereby declare that the sewerage system of the City consisting of the collection system (as hereinafter defined), waste collection and disposal operations, sewerage system and all other appurtenances, and equipment used for such purposes, or wastewater treatment facility (as hereinafter defined) shall be designated the Sewerage System Utility. This public utility is not a public service subject to regulation by the Wisconsin Public Service Commission for the purposes defined above. 
13.46 - MANAGEMENT. 
(1)  The operation management and control of the Sewerage System Utility is vested in the Common Council, acting as the Board of Public Works under the provisions of §66.066(1), Wis. Stats., and is hereinafter referred to as the "approving authority." All records of the Sewerage System Utility shall be kept by the Operations Manager in the City Hall or other officially designated place. (Am. #10-O781) 
(2)  The rules, regulations and rates hereinafter set forth shall be considered part of the regulations applicable to every individual or entity connected to the sewerage system and all persons discharging wastes to the sewerage system. Such rules, regulations and rates may be changed from time to time as determined by the Common Council and the right is reserved to make special rates and contracts in all proper cases. 
(3)  The Common Council shall cause an annual audit of the books of the Sewerage System Utility to be made and shall make the books and records relating to the Sewerage System Utility available for inspection during regular business hours. 
(4)  A proportionate distribution of operation, maintenance and replacement costs shall be maintained among other user classes. Users shall be notified annually of the sewer service charges associated with the sewerage system. 
(5)  The Sewerage System Utility shall be able to utilize the full authority provided in §66.076 Wis. Stats., with respect to financing methods, sewerage service charges, and other matters therein dealt with, and shall have all legal authority permitted for municipal utilities to charge reasonable rates for services. 
13.47 - APPLICATION. 
The application of this subchapter, its rules, regulations and rates shall apply to all individuals, firms, corporations and institutions residing within the corporate limit of the City and any person, firm or corporation, by attachment to the sewerage system or otherwise by contract or agreement coming within the City sewer service area subsequent to the effective date hereof and all entities hauling wastes or trucking wastes and discharging to the sewerage system. 
13.48 - DEFINITIONS. 
The meaning of terms used in this subchapter shall be as follows: 
Act. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 USC 1251 et seq.) as amended by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972 (P.L. 92-500) and P.L. 93-243, or as modified by Ch. 147, Wis. Stats., or appropriate sections of the Wisconsin Administrative Code adopted pursuant to Ch. 147. 
Approving authority. The Common Council or its authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
BOD. The quantity of oxygen expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l), utilized in the bio-chemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory conditions for 5 days at a temperature of 20°C. The laboratory determinations shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in "Standard Methods." 
Building sewer, lateral or service pipe. A sewer which carries only sewage or industrial wastes from the building plumbing to the public sanitary sewer. 
Capital costs. The cost of acquiring, purchasing, leasing, planning, designing, constructing, extending and improving all or any part of the sewerage system and of paying principal, interest or premiums on any indebtedness incurred for these purposes. Capital costs may be recovered through a utility rate-making model which includes components for depreciation and return on invested capital. 
Commercial user. (Am. #00-0473) Any property occupied by a nonresidential establishment not within the definition of an "industrial user", and which is connected to the wastewater facilities. 
Collection system. The system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection, transportation and pumping of domestic wastewater and industrial use. 
Connection. Each physical connection to the collection system or private sewer system which connects to the municipal collection system. 
Connection charge. A charge levied on users annually for each lateral connected to the public sanitary sewer. The revenues generated from the connection charge shall be used to cover expenditures relating to customer costs and costs related to flow not attributable to users (infiltration/inflow). 
Debt retirement. All annual principal and interest requirements and obligations of the approving authority for the wastewater treatment facility. 
Discharge. The introduction of pollutants into the Wastewater Treatment facility from any nondomestic source regulated under §307(b), (c) or (d) of the Federal Act. 
Discharge monitoring station. A sampling and metering station required to be installed through a discharge monitoring agreement signed by an industrial user with the City in order to obtain information on that user's discharge to the system and to establish sewer user and debt charges. 
Domestic wastewater. Waterborne wastes normally being discharged from the sanitary conveniences of dwellings, apartment houses, hotels, office buildings, factories and institutions, free of industrial wastes and in which the average concentration of suspended solids is established at or below 270 mg/l and the BOD is established at or below 250 mg/l. 
Flow proportional composite sample. A sample consisting of portions of waste taken in proportion to the volume of flow of such wastes. 
Indirect discharge. See: Discharge. 
Industrial cost recovery. Recovery by the approving authority from the industrial users of the sewerage system of the amount allowable for the treatment of wastes from such users pursuant to §204(b) of the Federal Act. 
Industrial user. (Am. #00-0473) Any nonresidential user identified in Division A, B, D, E, or I of the Standard Industrial Classifications Manual. Industrial user also shall include any user that discharges wastewater containing toxic or poisonous substances as defined in §307 or §502 of the Clean Air Act, or any substance(s) causing interference within the wastewater facilities. Industrial user shall include any nonresidential user who: 1) is subject to national categorical pretreatment standards, 2) has a nondomestic flow of 25,000 gallons or more per average work day, 3) contributes more than 5 percent of the average dry weather capacity of the wastewater facility, or 4) is determined by the Approving Authority or Operations Manager to have the potential to adversely affect the wastewater facility. 
Industrial waste. Any waterborne solids, liquids or gaseous wastes other than domestic wastewater, resulting from discharge from, flow from or escape from any commercial, industrial, manufacturing or food processing operation or process: from the development of any natural resource; or any mixture of these with water or domestic wastewater. 
Intercepting sewer. A sewer constructed to receive the dry weather flow of untreated or inadequately treated sewage from one or more existing sanitary sewer system terminals other than from a dwelling or building that presently discharges or formerly discharged flow directly into any waters of the State and convey the flow to a wastewater treatment facility, or is to serve in lieu of an existing or proposed wastewater treatment facility. 
Interference. The inhibition or disruption of any sewer system, wastewater treatment process, sludge disposal system, or their operation, which substantially contributes to a violation of applicable discharge permits. 
Natural outlet. Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or groundwater. 
Normal sewage. Sanitary sewage in which BOD and total suspended solids concentrations do not exceed normal concentration of: 
(a)  A 5-day 20°C BOD of not more than 250 parts per million. 
(b)  A total suspended solids concentration of not more than 270 parts per million. 
Operation and Maintenance cost (O&M). The actual sums spent by the City in the operation and maintenance of its sewerage system consisting of, but not limited to, each and all of the following purposes: 
(a)  Wages and salaries of employees related to expenses of operation, maintenance, clerical, laboratory and supervisory personnel, together with fringe benefits and premiums paid on such wages and salaries for the State Workmen's Compensation coverage. 
(b)  Electrical power and other utility services. 
(c)  Chemicals, fuel and other operating supplies. 
(d)  Repairs to and maintenance of associated equipment. 
(e)  Premiums for hazard insurance. 
(f)  Premiums for insurance providing coverage against liability for the injury to persons and/or property. 
(g)  Rents and leasing costs. 
(h)  Operation, licensing and maintenance costs for trucks and heavy equipment. 
(i)  Consultant and legal fees. 
(j)  Training and educational expenses. 
Operations Manager. The Operations Manager of the wastewater treatment and conveyance facilities, who shall be in charge of and supervise the operations and functions of the wastewater treatment and conveyance facilities and who shall report to the City Administrator. 
Persons. Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any individual, firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association, governmental agency or other entity and agents, servants or employees. 
pH. The logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen concentration expressed in moles per liter. It shall be determined by one of the procedures outlined in "Standard Methods". 
Pretreatment. The reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater before discharge to the City wastewater facilities. 
Private sewer. A privately owned sewer serving 2 or more buildings and not directly controlled by a public authority. 
Public sewer. A sewer or lateral in a public right-of-way or easement abutting properties and that is controlled or owned by the public authority. 
Replacement fund. Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories and appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were designed and constructed. 
Residential equivalency charge. A charge levied on nonmetered users for operation and maintenance, replacement, capital and depreciation. The charge shall be based on the average gallons of water used by a residential customer for operation and maintenance, replacement, capital and depreciation. 
Residential Equivalent Connection (REC). The wastewater flow and loadings to the system equivalent to that contributed by an average residential family equivalent. An average residential family equivalent shall be calculated yearly by the City based upon the residential water used divided by the total number of residential customers. 
Residential user. (Am. #00-0473) All premises used only for human residency and that are connected to the wastewater facilities. 
Sanitary sewer. A sewer that conveys domestic wastewater or industrial waste, or a combination of both and into which storm, surface and groundwater or unpolluted industrial wastewater are not intentionally contributed. 
Septage. Scum, liquid, sludge or other waste from a septic tank, soil absorption field, holding tank, vault toilet or privy. This does not include the waste from a grease trap. 
Sewerage system. All facilities for collecting, transporting, pumping, treating and disposing of domestic wastewater, industrial wastes and septage. Also may be referred to as sewer system. 
Sewer availability charge. A charge levied on all new users of the sewage system or current users who expand their use of the sewer service system. This charge shall be based upon the historic costs existing customers have contributed to the sewer facility infrastructure and the loss of interest thereon. Funds collected from sewer availability charges shall be used to finance improvements to the sewer service system. 
Slug. Any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period longer than 15 minutes more than 5 times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operation and which adversely affects the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater treatment facility. 
Standard methods. The examination and analytical procedures set forth in the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" as prepared, approved and published jointly by the American Public Health Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
Storm sewer. A sewer which carries storm and surface drainage, but excludes domestic wastewater and industrial wastes. 
Surcharge user. A user of the sewerage system who discharges wastes which have higher concentrations than domestic wastewater and is assessed an additional charge (surcharge) for the constituents higher in concentration than domestic wastewater. 
Total Suspended Solids (TSS). Solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids and which are removable by a laboratory filtration device. Quantitative determination of total suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in "Standard Methods." Also referred to as suspended solids. 
Toxics. Any of the pollutants defined by federal regulations pursuant to §307(a)(1) of the Act. 
Unpolluted water. Water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharging to the sanitary sewers and Wastewater Treatment Facility provided. 
Use factors. Flow, BOD, total suspended solids and infiltration/inflow or the quantity of these factors as determined by the City by sampling and monitoring the Wastewater Treatment Facility influent and surcharge users and from the Water Utility records. 
User. Any person discharging domestic wastewater or industrial wastes into the collection system or entity discharging septage or other waste hauled or tracked to the sewerage system. 
User charge. A charge levied on users to recover the component of total operation, maintenance and capital costs of the sewerage system which relates to sewage flow generated by users of the system. The sewer use charge shall consist of a volumetric charge in terms of dollars per thousand gallons ($/1,000 gals.). 
Waste. Any solids, liquid or gaseous material or combination thereof discharged from any residences, business buildings, institutions, industrial establishments and septage haulers into the collection system, storm sewer or septage receiving station. 
Wastewater. A combination of the water carried waste discharged into the collection system from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such ground, surface and storm water as may be present. 
Wastewater pumping station. A pumping facility utilized to pump wastewater within the collection system. 
Wastewater Treatment Facilities (WTF). Any City-owned facility, devices and structures used for receiving and treating wastewater from the City collection system. 
Water Utility. The Oconomowoc Water Utility. 
WPDES permit. A permit to discharge pollutants obtained under the Wisconsin Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (WPDES), pursuant to Ch. 147, Wis. Stats. 
13.49 - RULES AND REGULATIONS. 
(1)  DECLARATION OF POLICY. The Common Council finds and declares that the public health, comfort and safety is preserved and enhanced by the provision of the sewerage system in the promotion of a clean and healthful environment and that the failure to connect to the sewerage system is contrary to minimum health standards. 
(2)  CONNECTION. 
(a)  To assure preservation of public health, comfort and safety, the owner of any house, building or property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other habitation, situated within the City and adjacent to a public sewer or in a block through which a public sewer extends, is hereby required at his or her expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this subchapter within 12 months after the public sewer first becomes operational or, if an immediate health hazard exists, within 10 days upon receipt of notice from the county health officer or the City Building Inspector. Also see §11.07. 
(b)  If a person fails to comply with the notice to connect within the given period of time, the City may, at its option: 
1.  Cause such connection to be made and bill the property owner for such costs. If such costs are not paid within 30 days, such costs shall be assessed as a special tax lien against the property, unless the owner within 30 days after the completion of the work files a sworn affidavit with the City Clerk stating that he or she cannot pay such amount in one sum and asking that it be levied in not to exceed 5 equal annual installments and the amount that shall be so collected with interest at a rate which is sufficient to recover the City's costs of borrowed funds or interest lost plus one percentage point per annum from the completion of the work, the unpaid balance to be a special tax lien. 
2.  Impose a standby charge for the period of time in excess of 12 months that such failure continues after the date the public sewer first becomes operational, after 10 days' written notice to any owner failing to make a connection to the sewerage system, for an amount equal to 150 percent of the annual connection charge, payable monthly for the period in which the failure to connect continues. Upon failure to make such payment, such charge shall be levied as a tax against the lot or parcel to which sewerage service was furnished. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection 13.49(2)(a), the installation of all sanitary sewer mains and laterals and the connection and service to be provided to Town of Summit properties attached to the City shall be as provided in the following paragraphs: (Cr. #10-O768) 
1.  Individual Developed Properties. Connection to sanitary sewer will be required for all properties upon private septic system failure. Exception: Replacement of private septic systems with replacement systems will be permitted if sewer is not available and state and county regulations allow replacement. 
2.  Deferring of Connection. If sewer is extended to adjacent properties with failing septic systems, properties with working systems can be deferred from connection for up to 12 years from the date sewer becomes available. Assessment for sewer mains can be deferred for up to 12 years from the date sewer becomes available or until connection to a sewer main, whichever occurs first. Interest will be charged on deferred assessments. 
3.  Riverline Subdivision. Connection to sanitary sewer will be required for all properties upon private septic system failure. When sewer is extended to serve this subdivision, properties with working systems (certified by Waukesha County) can be deferred from connection for up to 12 years from the date sewer becomes available. Assessment for sewer mains can be deferred for up to 12 years from the date sewer becomes available or until connection to a sewer main, whichever occurs first. Interest will be charged on deferred assessments. 
4.  Paganica Court Subdivision. (Cr. #15-O872) This subsection applies to all properties, improved and unimproved, which currently consists of 5 single-family residential lots on Paganica Court extending from Silver Lake Street to its terminus. When and if sewer is extended to serve this subdivision, properties with working systems (certified by Waukesha County) can be deferred from connection for up to 12 years from the date sewer becomes available. Assessment for sewer mains can be deferred for up to 12 years from the date that sewer becomes available or until connection to a sewer main, whichever occurs first. Interest will be charged on deferred assessments. With regard to the 5 lots in this subdivision or any newly-created lots, private septic systems shall be authorized if sewer has not been installed in this subdivision. Replacement of private septic systems will be permitted if sewer is not available and if state and county regulations allow replacement. 
5.  Vacant or Undeveloped Land. (Am. #15-O872) Development or improvement of vacant land will be permitted only when sewer and water is available to the land being improved. 
6.  Temporary Connection to Sewer. (Am. #15-O872) If a residential or commercial septic system fails and a temporary connection can be made to an existing sewer main, a temporary connection will be permitted under the following conditions: 
a.  Property owner agrees to pay all costs of temporary connection and acquires all necessary easements; 
b.  Property owner agrees to connect to permanent main when it becomes available; 
c.  Property owner agrees to install service per City specifications; and 
d.  Property owner agrees to pay the assessment for the permanent main when it is installed. 
7.  Maintenance of Septic Systems. (Am. #15-O872) Division 3 of Article XIII of Chapter 14 of the Waukesha County Code of Ordinances titled "Private Sewage Systems" as presently constituted, or as amended or renumbered, is incorporated herein by reference as though set forth in full verbatim. Section 14-589 titled "Private Sewage System Maintenance" sets forth a maintenance program for private sewage systems. Subsection 1 requires that all septic tanks and lift pump tanks shall be pumped and inspected within two years of the date of installation, and at least once every two years thereafter. Subsection 14 provides that failure to maintain the private sewage system or provide documentation of its maintenance as required by Section 14-589 may subject the owner to penalties allowed under state law and/or county ordinance. In addition, the failure to maintain or otherwise violate Division 3 of Article XIII may result in penalties as provided in the City of Oconomowoc Municipal Code. 
(3)  ALTERNATIVE DISPOSAL PROHIBITED. 
(a)  No person shall construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended to be used for the disposal of domestic wastewater if a public sewer is available. 
(b)  No person shall discharge to any natural outlet within the City in any area under the jurisdiction of the City sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this subchapter. 
(4)  PLUMBERS. No plumber or other person will be permitted to engage in or work at any plumbing in connection with the sewerage system without first receiving a license from the State Bureau of Plumbing. 
(5)  MAINTENANCE OF LATERALS. All laterals located in the public right-of-way or easements from the point of connection, including connecting device, to the sewer main and all facilities throughout the premises served must be maintained free of defective conditions by, and at the expense of, the owner of the property served. 
(6)  USERS. 
(a)  Application for Service. 
1.  Every person requesting connection to the sewerage system shall file an application in writing to the City in such form as is prescribed for that purpose. Blanks for such applications will be furnished at the office of the Building Inspector. The application must state fully and truly all the use which will presently be made. If any change in use from that set forth in this application is contemplated, the user must obtain further application and permission from the Operations Manager. If the applicant is not the owner of the premises, the written consent of the owner must accompany the application. (Am. #10-O781) 
2.  The application may be for service to more than one building or more than one unit of service through one service connection and, in such case, charges shall be made accordingly. 
3.  If it appears that the service applied for will not provide adequate service for the contemplated use, the City Engineer may reject the application. If the City Engineer approves the application, the City Engineer shall authorize the Building Inspector to issue a permit, after appropriate fees are paid, for services as shown on the application. 
4.  All expenses relating to the connection to the sewerage system shall be paid by the applicant or owner at the time of permit issuance. 
(b)  Tap Permits. After sewer connections have been installed into any building or upon any premises, no plumber shall make any alterations, extensions or attachments, unless the party ordering such tapping or other work shall obtain and exhibit the proper permit for the same from the City Engineer. 
(c)  User to Keep in Good Repair. All users shall keep their own service pipes in good repair and protected from frost at their own risk and expense and shall prevent any unnecessary overburdening of the sewerage system. The user is responsible for their service pipe from the street main through their facility served. 
(d)  User Use Only . No user shall allow other persons to connect to or permit other uses to be made of the sewerage system through his or her lateral. 
(e)  User to Permit Inspection . Every user shall permit the City or its authorized agent at all reasonable hours of the day to enter their premises or building to examine the pipes and fixtures and the manner in which the drains and sewer connections operate and they must at all times, frankly and without concealment, answer all questions put to them relative to its use. Should the owner or occupant of the premises refuse voluntary access to the premises, the Plumbing Inspector is authorized to seek a special inspection warrant under §66.122, Wis. Stats. 
(f)  Responsibility . No claim shall be made against the City or its agents or employees by reasons of the breaking, clogging, stoppage or freezing of any service pipe, nor from any damage arising from repairing mains, making connections or extensions or any other work that may be deemed necessary by the City absent of gross negligence of the City, its agents or employees. The City may cut off the service at any time for the purpose of repairs or any other necessary purpose, any permit granted or regulation to the contrary notwithstanding. Whenever it shall become necessary to shut off the sewer service within an area of the City, the City shall, if practicable, give notice to each affected user. 
(7)  EXCAVATIONS. Excavation requirements in any easement or public right-of-way shall be as specified and required by the authority having jurisdiction over such easement or right-of-way. In all cases, a permit is required and construction methods shall conform to §8.04 of this Municipal Code. 
(8)  LATERALS. 
(a)  All laterals on private property will be installed in accordance with the Wisconsin Administrative Code as from time to time amended. 
(b)  The building sewer shall be inspected by the Plumbing Inspector or his/her designee upon completion of placement of the pipe and before backfilling, and tested before and after backfilling. The Plumbing Inspector or his/her designee may order any building sewer exposed and removed if such building sewer is covered before inspection. 
(9)  TAPPING THE MAINS. 
(a)  No persons, except those having special permission from the City or persons in their service and approved by them, will be permitted under any circumstances to tap the public sanitary sewers. The kind and size of the connection to the public sanitary sewers shall be that specified in the permit or order from the City. A minimum of 48 hours notice shall be given to the City prior to tapping any main. 
(b)  Pipes should always be tapped at the top and not within 6 inches of the joint or within 24 inches of another lateral connection. 
(c)  When any building sewer service is to be relaid and there are 2 or more buildings on such service, each building shall be disconnected from such service and a new building sewer shall be installed for each building. 
(d)  No sewer service (lateral) shall be laid to service an accessory building located on any lot used for residential purposes. (Cr. #00-0473) 
(10)  SEPTAGE DISPOSAL. 
(a)  All septage disposers shall be licensed in accordance with §146.20(3), Wis. Stats. 
(b)  All septage disposers wishing to discharge to the City Wastewater Treatment Facility (WTF) shall possess a septage disposers discharge permit prior to disposing of any wastes at the WTF. Every licensed disposer wishing to discharge septage shall file a nonrefundable filing fee and an application in writing to the Operations Manager in such a form as is prescribed for that purpose. Forms for such application will be furnished by the Operations Manager. The Operations Manager will evaluate the applications and make a determination as to the amount and conditions of septage disposal at the WTF. Every septage disposer shall file a certificate of insurance with the City prior to the City issuing a discharge permit. The insurable amount shall be equal to $300,000.00 for general liability, $300,000.00 for automobile liability and the statutory limit for workers compensation. (Am. #10-O781) 
(c)  Each truck of a permitted septage disposer discharging to the WTF shall be registered with the City. Registered trucks will be issued identification stickers and numbers which shall be clearly displayed on the rear end and both sides of the truck. Any unregistered truck or registered truck without identification stickers and numbers will not be allowed to discharge until properly registered with identification stickers exhibited. 
(d)  Each septage disposal permit shall be issued subject to the conditions that if at any time the WTF has operational problems, maintenance problems or threat of a WPDES permit violation that are indirectly or directly related to septage disposal, the City may immediately restrict septage waste disposal until such time as corrective action or mitigative measures have been taken. Restriction may include prohibition of disposal of septage waste. 
(e)  The WTF will accept only hauled septage waste from domestic origin and permitted industrial or commercial septage waste. Septage disposers must characterize the septage they haul to the WTF. Hauled industrial and/or commercial septage will not be accepted, unless the industry or commercial establishment has received a wastewater discharge permit as specified in this section or has received permission from the City. Any new industrial or commercial septage must be reported to the City by the septage disposer.
