Grantee expressly acknowledges that in accepting a Franchise it does so relying on its own investigation and understanding of the power and authority of the City to grant the Franchise. 
By accepting a Franchise, a Grantee acknowledges that it has not been induced to enter into the Franchise by any understanding or promise or other statement, whether verbal or written, by or on behalf of the City or by any other third person concerning any term or condition of the Franchise not expressed herein. 
The Grantee further acknowledges by acceptance of the Franchise that it has carefully read the terms and conditions hereof, and is willing to and does accept all the risks of the meaning of such terms and conditions. 
22.27 - WORK PERFORMED BY OTHERS. 
(A)  A Grantee shall give prior notice to the City specifying the names and addresses of any entity, other than the Grantee, that performs substantial services pursuant to the Franchise, provided, however, that all provisions of the Franchise remain the responsibility of the Grantee. All personnel of the Grantee or its subcontractors shall carry and display if requested a photo I.D. identifying themselves as representatives of the Grantee when performing services at subscriber locations in the City. 
(B)  All provisions of a Franchise shall apply to any subcontractor or others performing any work or services pursuant to the provisions of the Franchise. 
22.28 - CONTEST OF VALIDITY. 
Grantee agrees by acceptance of a Franchise that it will not at any time set up against the City in a claim for proceeding any condition or term of the Franchise as unreasonable, arbitrary or void, or that the City had no power or authority to make such term or condition, but shall be required to accept the validity of the terms and conditions of the Franchise in their entirety. 
22.29 - CUSTOMER SERVICE STANDARDS. 
The Grantee shall maintain resources sufficient and near enough to the franchise territory to provide the necessary facilities, equipment and personnel to comply with this section and other provisions of this Ordinance. 
(A)  Service Standards . The Grantee shall render efficient service, make repairs promptly and interrupt service between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and l:00 a.m. only for good cause and for the shortest possible time. Service may be interrupted between 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. for routine testing, maintenance and repair, except on nights commencing on Saturday and Sunday and on holidays. Scheduled or predictable service interruptions, except for weekly routine maintenance, insofar as possible shall be preceded by notice, which may be provided across the cable system. The interruptions shall occur during periods of minimum use of the system to the extent practicable. The Grantee shall maintain a written log or an equivalent capable of access and reproduction of all service interruptions and requests for service, which log shall be available for City inspection during the franchise period. 
(B)  Telephone Lines . The Grantee shall provide local toll-free or collect call telephone access to its subscribers within the franchise territory. Any calls should be answered by a customer service representative during Normal Business Hours; calls outside this period may be answered by an automated response mechanism, but such calls should be processed by a Grantee's representative within 12 hours. The Grantee shall provide sufficient phone answering capacity that customer calls are answered on average within 30 seconds 90 percent of the time; and that customers receive a busy signal no more than 3 percent of the time 90 percent of the time on an overall basis. Violations of these standards shall be subject to penalties under provisions of §22.16. Upon request by the City, Grantee will provide records demonstrating compliance with this provision. 
(C)  Installation . The Grantee shall complete requests for subscriber installations within 7 business days of order placement when the installation is within 150 feet of the existing cable system. Installation requests required to be honored under this Ordinance beyond the 150-foot standard must be completed within 14 days. If the Grantee fails to meet these standards the Grantee shall provide the subscriber with a free month of the requested service. The Grantee may request the City toll these periods for reasonable circumstances beyond its control. 
(D)  Repair Standards . The Grantee shall maintain a repair force capable, under normal operating circumstances, of responding to service interruption and degradation complaints made during Normal Business Hours within 4 hours. For complaints made outside Normal Business Hours, the Grantee must respond within 16 hours. For the purpose of this subsection, "response" shall mean at a minimum contacting the subscriber by phone or in person. Where a Grantee misses either of these deadlines, Grantee must provide the subscriber with one free month's service. The Grantee may request the City toll the repair period for reasonable circumstances beyond its control. 
(E)  Service Call Scheduling . When the Grantee needs to arrange a service appointment at a subscriber's location, the Grantee must offer the subscriber a service window not to exceed 4 hours in duration. Grantee may not cancel a service window without the subscriber's consent. Where a Grantee misses a service window, Grantee must provide the subscriber with one free month's service. The Grantee may request the City toll the service call period for reasonable circumstances beyond its control. 
(F)  Service Interruptions and Significant Degradation . When the Grantee has failed to provide a subscriber with appropriate service due to service outage or significant audio or video degradation not due to the subscriber's equipment or action, the subscriber may request a rebate of any fees paid for the affected service(s) under the following schedule, and the Grantee must provide such rebates. For the purposes of this section the outage or degradation period shall begin when the subscriber provides notice to the Grantee of the outage or degradation. The Grantee may request the City waive or modify the rebate provisions for reasonable circumstances beyond its control. 
(1)  For periods at least 4 hours long but under 24 hours, a rebate of one-thirtieth of the monthly fee for affected services for each instance. 
(2)  For periods of at least 24 hours, a rebate of one-tenth of the monthly fee for affected services for each 24-hour period or portion thereof. 
CHAPTER 25 - CONSTRUCTION AND EFFECT OF ORDINANCES 
25.01 Rules of Construction 25.02 Conflict and Separability 25.03 Clerk to File Documents Incorporated by Reference 25.04 Penalty Provisions 25.05 Repeal of General Ordinances 25.06 Effect of Repeals 25.07 Title; Effective Date; Citation 25.08 Keeping Code Current; Revisor's Amendments  

25.01 - RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. 
In the construction of this Code of general ordinances, the following rules shall be observed unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the ordinance: 
(1)  WISCONSIN STATUTES. (Am. MSC '93; MSC '95) All references to "Wisconsin Statutes" or "Wis. Stats." means the current edition of the Wisconsin Statutes and includes the most recent biennial session. 
(2)  GENDER, SINGULAR AND PLURAL. Every word in this Code and in any ordinance imparting the masculine gender may extend and be applied to females as well as males, and every word imparting the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons or things as well as to one person or thing; provided these rules of construction shall not be applied to any provision which contains any express language excluding such construction or when the subject matter or context of such provision may be repugnant thereto. 
(3)  PERSON. The word "person" extends and applies to natural persons, firms, corporations, associations, partnerships or other bodies politic and all entities capable of being sued, unless plainly inapplicable. 
(4)  ACTS OF AGENTS. When a provision requires an act to be done which may, by law, as well be done by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be construed to include all such acts when done by an authorized agent. 
25.02 - CONFLICT AND SEPARABILITY. 
(1)  CONFLICT OF PROVISIONS. If the provisions of the different chapters of this Code conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions of each chapter shall prevail as to all matters and questions arising out of the subject matter of such chapter. 
(2)  SEPARABILITY OF CODE PROVISIONS. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause of phrase of the Code is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by reason of any decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of any other section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase or portion thereof. The Council hereby declares that they would have passed this Code and each section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections, subsections, sentences, clauses, phrases or portions may be declared invalid or unconstitutional. 
25.03 - CLERK TO FILE DOCUMENTS INCORPORATED BY REFERENCE. 
Whenever in this Code any standard, code, rule, regulation or other written or printed matter is adopted by reference, it shall be deemed incorporated in this Code as if fully set forth herein and the Clerk shall file, deposit and keep in his/her office a copy of the code, standard, rule, regulation or other written or printed matter as adopted. Materials so filed, deposited and kept shall be public records open for examination with proper care by any person during the Clerk's office hours, subject to such orders or regulations which the Clerk may prescribe for their preservation. 
25.04 - PENALTY PROVISIONS. 
(1)  GENERAL PENALTY. (Am. #12-O835) Except as otherwise provided, any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this Code shall, upon conviction of such violation, be subject to a penalty, which shall be as follows: 
(a)  First Offense . Any person who shall violate any provision of this Code shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $5.00 nor more than $1,000.00, together with the costs of prosecution, and in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs of prosecution shall be imprisoned in the County Jail until such forfeiture and costs are paid, but not exceeding 90 days. 
(b)  Second Offense . Any person found guilty of violating any ordinance or part of an ordinance of this Code who has previously been convicted of a violation of the same ordinance within one year shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $10.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for each such offense, together with the costs of prosecution, and in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs shall be imprisoned in the County Jail until such forfeiture and costs are paid, but not exceeding 6 months. 
(c)  Third Offense . Shall be a forfeiture of not less than $15.00 nor more than $1,500.00, together with the cost of prosecution. 
(2)  CONTINUED VIOLATIONS. Each violation and each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense. Nothing in this Code shall preclude the City from maintaining any appropriate action to prevent or remove a violation of any provision of this Code. 
(3)  EXECUTION AGAINST DEFENDANT'S PROPERTY. Whenever any person fails to pay any forfeiture and costs of prosecution upon the order of any court for violation of any ordinance of the City, the court may, in lieu of ordering imprisonment of the defendant or after the defendant has been released from custody, issue an execution against the property of the defendant for such forfeiture and costs. 
(4)  CITATION METHOD OF ENFORCEMENT. (Cr. #89-0210) 
(a)  Authority. Pursuant to the authority of §66.119, Wis. Stats., the City hereby elects to use the citation method of enforcement of ordinances, including those for which a statutory counterpart exists. 
(b)  Citation. 
1.  The citation shall contain the following: 
a.  The name, address and date of birth of the defendant. 
b.  The name and department of the issuing officer. 
c.  The violation alleged, the time and place of occurrence, a statement that the defendant committed the violation, the ordinance, resolution or bylaw violated and a designation of the violation in language which can be readily understood. 
d.  A date, time and place for the court appearance and a notice to appear. 
e.  Provisions that a cash deposit based on a schedule established by this subsection may be made which shall be delivered or mailed to the Clerk of Municipal Court in lieu of a court appearance unless subsequently summoned to appear. 
f.  Notice that if the defendant makes a deposit and fails to appear in court at the time fixed in the citation, the defendant is deemed to have entered a plea of no contest and submits to a forfeiture and penalty assessment plus costs, including the fee prescribed in §814.65(1), Wis. Stats., not to exceed the amount of the deposit, or will be summoned into court to answer the complaint if the court does not accept the plea of no contest. 
g.  Notice that if the defendant does not make a deposit and fails to appear in court at the time fixed in the citation, the court may issue a summons or a warrant for the defendant's arrest, may enter a default judgment against the defendant or an action may be commenced to collect the forfeiture up to the maximum permitted by law. 
h.  Notice that the defendant may by mail and prior to the court appearance date enter a plea of not guilty. The court will mail the defendant a pretrial date. The trial will be held before the Municipal Court. After the court trial, State statutes dictate the defendant's right to a jury trial. 
i.  A direction that if the alleged violator elects to make a cash deposit, the statement which accompanies the citation shall be signed to indicate that the statement required under subpar. f., above, has been read. Such statement shall be sent or brought with the cash deposit. 
j.  Any other pertinent information as the City deems necessary. 
2.  The form of the citation is incorporated into this subsection by reference. 
(c)  Schedule of Deposits. 
1.  The schedule of cash deposits for use with citations issued under this subsection shall be as adopted by the Municipal Court for Western Waukesha County or if not included in the schedule of deposits adopted by the court, as adopted by the City Council from time to time, and such schedule shall be on file in the offices of the Chief of Police and Clerk. 
2.  Deposits shall be made in cash, money order or certified check to the Clerk of Municipal Court who shall provide a receipt therefor. 
(d)  Issuance of Citations. 
1.  Any law enforcement officer may issue citations for enforcement of any ordinances authorized under this subsection. 
2.  The following officials of the City are hereby authorized to issue citations for enforcement of those ordinances specified. Such officials may delegate this authority to their subordinates upon approval of the City Council. 
Enforcement Official Title and Chapter Building Inspector Building Code (Ch. 14) Building/Plumbing Inspector Plumbing Code (Ch. 14) Building/Electrical Inspector Electrical Code (Ch. 14) Building Inspector Property Maintenance Code (Ch. 15) Zoning Administrator/City Engineer Shoreland-Wetland Zoning Code (Ch. 16) Zoning Administrator/City Engineer Zoning Code (Ch. 17) Zoning Administrator/City Engineer Subdivision and Platting (Ch. 18) Zoning Administrator/City Engineer Floodplain Zoning Code (Ch. 19) Fire Inspector Fire Protection Code (Ch. 5) Police Chief, Fire Chief or Building Inspector Public Nuisances (Ch. 10) County Health Department, City Engineer or Building Inspector Public Health & Welfare (Ch. 11) Director of Utilities and City Engineer Municipal Utilities (Ch. 13) Building Inspector Signs (Ch. 26)  
(e)  Procedure. The provisions of §66.119(3), Wis. Stats., relating to violator's options and procedure on default, are hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference. 
(f)  Nonexclusivity. Adoption of this subsection in no way precludes the adoption of any other ordinance or providing for the enforcement of any other law or ordinance relating to the same or any other matter. The issuance of a citation under this subsection in no way precludes the proceeding under any other law or ordinance relating to the same or any other matter. 
25.05 - REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES. 
All ordinances heretofore adopted by the City Council are hereby repealed, except all ordinances or parts of ordinances relating to the following subjects and not conflicting with any of the provisions of this Code: 
(1)  The issuance of corporate bonds and notes of the City of whatever name or description. 
(2)  The establishment of grades, curb lines and widths of sidewalks in the public streets and alleys. 
(3)  The fixing of salaries of public officials and employees. 
(4)  Rights, licenses or franchises or the creation of any contract with the City. 
(5)  The lighting of streets and alleys. 
(6)  The annexation of territory to the City. 
(7)  The naming and changing of names of streets, alleys, public grounds and parks. 
(8)  The letting of contracts without bids. 
(9)  The establishment of aldermanic districts, aldermanic district boundaries and election precincts. 
(10)  Tax and special assessment levies. 
(11)  Releases of persons, firms or corporations from liability. 
(12)  Construction of public works. 
(13)  Water, sewer and electric rates, rules and regulations and sewer and water main construction. 
(14)  Budget ordinances, resolutions and actions. 
25.06 - EFFECT OF REPEALS. 
The repeal or amendment of any section or provision of this Code or of any other ordinance or resolution of the Council shall not: 
(1)  By implication be deemed to revive any ordinance not in force or existing at the time such repeal or amendment takes effect. 
(2)  Affect any vested right, privilege, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or incurred under any enactment so repealed or amended, unless the privilege of repealing such obligation or privilege has been reserved by the City. 
(3)  Affect any offense committed, or penalty or forfeiture incurred, previous to the time when any ordinance is repealed or amended; except when any forfeiture or penalty has been mitigated by the provisions of any ordinance, such provisions shall apply to and control any judgment to be pronounced after such ordinance takes effect for any offense committed before that time. 
(4)  Affect any prosecution for any offense, or the levy of any penalty or forfeiture pending at the time when any ordinance aforesaid is repealed or amended; but the right of action shall continue and the offender shall be subject to the penalty as provided in such ordinance, and such prosecution shall proceed, in all respects, as if such ordinance had not been repealed; except all such proceedings had after the time this Code takes effect shall be conducted according to the provisions of this Code. 
25.07 - TITLE; EFFECTIVE DATE; CITATION. 
These ordinances shall be known as the "Municipal Code of the City of Oconomowoc" and shall take effect from and after passage and publication as provided in §66.035, Wis. Stats. All references thereto shall be cited by section number (example: §13.06, Municipal Code of the City of Oconomowoc). 
25.08 - KEEPING CODE CURRENT; REVISOR'S AMENDMENTS. 
As each ordinance or resolution affecting the Municipal Code becomes effective, the City Clerk shall forward such ordinance or resolution to the Revisor, who shall incorporate same into the Municipal Code. The Revisor shall make no substantive changes to such ordinances and resolutions but may renumber, rearrange and edit them without first submitting them to the City Council; and such rearranging, renumbering and editing shall not affect the validity of such ordinances and resolutions or the provisions of this Municipal Code affected thereby. 
CHAPTER 27 - IMPACT FEE ORDINANCE (Rep. & recr. #06-O668) 
27.01 Short Title 27.02 Intent 27.03 Authority 27.04 Definitions 27.05 Applicability of Impact Fee 27.06 Imposition of Impact Fee 27.07 Establishment of Development Subareas 27.08 Capital Improvements Program by Subarea 27.09 Impact Fee Schedules/Calculation 27.10 Calculation of Impact Fee 27.11 Administration of Impact Fee 27.12 Bonding of Excess Facility Projects 27.13 Refunds 27.14 Appeals 27.15 Effect of Impact Fee on Zoning and Subdivision Regulations 27.16 Impact Fee as Additional and Supplemental Requirement 27.17 Amendments 27.18 Credits 27.19 Penalty  

27.01 - SHORT TITLE . 
This Ordinance shall be known and cited as the "Impact Fee Ordinance". 
27.02 - INTENT . 
The purpose of this Ordinance is to impose impact fees in order to pay for capital costs or improvements which are necessary to accommodate new development or any improvements made to existing development in the City as a whole or in designated subareas. The imposition of impact fees is intended to ensure that capital facilities are adequate to meet the health and safety needs of the City and that new development pays a proportionate share of new or expanded capital facilities required by such development. 
27.03 - AUTHORITY . 
This Ordinance is authorized under §66.0617, Wis. Stats. The provisions of this Ordinance shall not be construed to limit the power of the City to adopt such Ordinance pursuant to any other source of local authority, nor to utilize any other methods or powers otherwise available for accomplishing the purposes set forth herein, either in substitution of or in conjunction with this Ordinance. 
27.04 - DEFINITIONS . 
As applied in this Ordinance, the following words and terms shall be used: 
(1)  BUILDING PERMIT shall mean any permit required for new construction and additions pursuant to Chapter 14 of the Municipal Code. The term "building permit," as used herein, shall not be deemed to include permits required for remodeling, rehabilitation, or other improvements to an existing structure, or rebuilding a damaged or destroyed structure, provided no increase in gross floor area or number of dwelling units results therefrom. 
(2)  CAPITAL BUDGET shall mean a plan for capital expenditures, including commitments, to be incurred during the budget year from funds subject to appropriation by the Common Council of the City of Oconomowoc for projects scheduled in a given year of the capital program. 
(3)  CAPITAL COSTS shall mean the capital cost to construct, expand or improve public facilities, including the cost of land, and including legal, engineering and design costs to construct, expand or improve public facilities, except that not more than 10 percent of capital costs may consist of legal, engineering and design costs unless the City can demonstrate that its legal, engineering and design costs which relate directly to the public improvement for which the impact fees were imposed exceed 10 percent of capital costs. "Capital costs" does not include other noncapital costs to construct, expand or improve public facilities, vehicles, or the costs of equipment to construct, expand or improve public facilities. 
(4)  CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS PROGRAM (CIP) shall mean a plan for capital expenditures, including commitments, to be incurred each year over a fixed period of years to meet capital needs arising from the long-term work program. It thus sets forth each project or other contemplated expenditure in which the City is to have a part, and it specifies the full resources estimated to be available to finance the projected expenditures. 
(5)  COMPREHENSIVE PLAN shall mean City of Oconomowoc Comprehensive Land Use Plan 2010-2030, including any subsequent changes or amendments thereto. (Am. #10-O782) 
(6)  DEVELOPER shall mean a person who constructs or creates a land development. 
(7)  DEVELOPMENT shall mean any manmade change to improved or unimproved real property, the use of any principal structure or land, or any other activity that requires issuance of a building permit. 
(8)  DEVELOPMENT SUBAREAS shall mean geographically defined areas of the City that have been designated by the City Council as areas in which development potential may create the need for a capital improvements program to be funded in whole or in part by impact fees. The areas may be referenced in the Comprehensive Plan, and shall be shown on a Development Subareas Map. 
(9)  DEVELOPMENT SUBAREAS MAP shall mean a map of development subareas in which impact fees are imposed. This map shall be approved by the City Council, and incorporated by reference herein as if fully set forth. This map shall be filed in the office of the City Clerk and the City Engineer. 
(10)  GROSS FLOOR AREA shall mean the sum of the total planned floor area of all floor levels of a building (in square feet), including cellars, basements, mezzanines, penthouses, corridors, lobbies, stores and offices that are within the principal outside faces of exterior walls, not including architectural setbacks or projections. Included are all areas that have floor surfaces with clear standing head room (6 feet, 6 inches minimum) regardless of their use. Unroofed areas and unenclosed roofed-over areas, except those contained within the principle outside faces of exterior walls, and parking garages are not included. 
(11)  IMPACT FEE means cash contributions, contributions of land or interest in land, or any other items of value that are imposed on a developer by a municipality under this chapter. Impact fee shall mean a fee to be collected within 14 days after a building permit is issued and calculated based upon the capital costs of facilities in proportion to development creating the need for such facilities. 
(12)  MIXED USE DEVELOPMENT shall mean local use of land involving both residential and nonresidential development. 
(13)  NONRESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT shall mean any local use of land for primarily industrial or commercial purposes, or which does not fall within the definition of residential development. 
(14)  PUBLIC FACILITIES means any or all of the following, which are necessary to support and are attributable to one or more designated development areas and which are identified in the capital improvement plan to be financed by the imposition of an impact fee: 
(a)  Parks, playgrounds and land for athletic fields. 
(b)  Highways, as defined in §340.01(22), Wis. Stats., and other transportation facilities. 
(c)  Traffic control devices. 
(d)  Facilities for collecting and treatment of sewage. 
(e)  Facilities for pumping, storing and distributing water. 
(f)  Facilities for collecting and treatment of storm and surface waters. 
(g)  Solid waste and recycling facilities. 
(h)  Law enforcement facilities. 
(i)  Fire protection and emergency medical facilities. 
(j)  Libraries. 
(k)  Any other necessary governmental facilities permitted under §66.0617, Wis. Stats. 
(15)  RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT shall mean local use of land for the primary purpose of housing accommodations. 
(16)  RESIDENTIAL EQUIVALENT CONNECTION (REC) shall mean a unit of measure for sewer or water related impact fees equivalent to the amount of sewer or water capacity needed to supply one residential dwelling unit. For the purposes of the impact fees established under this Ordinance, RECs shall be calculated as follows: 
(a)  North Interceptor Impact Fee . A sewer REC shall be equal to 176 gallons per day, or 64,240 gallons annualized. (Am. #10-O782) 
(b)  Second Street Lift Station Sewer Impact Fee . A sewer REC shall be equal to 192 gallons per day, or 70,080 gallons annualized. (Am. #10-O782) 
(c)  Water Facilities . A water REC shall be equal to 240 gallons per day, or 87,600 gallons annualized. (Cr. #10-O782; Am. #15-O881) 
(17)(a)  REDEVELOPMENT shall mean any existing building or structure that undergoes a change of use, intensification of use, increase in size, etc. (Cr. #10-0782; Am. #16-O899) 
(b)  HOTEL REDEVELOPMENT shall mean any existing hotel or motel that undergoes a change of use to multi-family residential. (Cr. #16-O899) 
(18)  SERVICE AREA shall mean a geographic area delineated by the City within which there are public facilities. 
(19)  SITE shall mean a parcel, lot, or contiguous group of lots in a single ownership or under single control, considered a unit for purposes of development. 
(20)  CITY shall mean the City of Oconomowoc, Wisconsin. 
(21)  CITY COUNCIL shall mean the Council of the City of Oconomowoc, Wisconsin. 
(22)  ZONING DISTRICTS shall mean a part or parts of the City for which the Zoning Code regulations governing the use and location of land and buildings are uniform. 
(23)  ZONING ORDINANCE shall mean the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Oconomowoc, Wisconsin. 
27.05 - APPLICABILITY OF IMPACT FEE . 
This Ordinance shall be uniformly applicable to development which occurs within the City as a whole or a designated development subarea. Pursuant to §66.0617(5), Wis. Stats., this Ordinance may impose different impact fees on different types of land development, and may impose impact fees on land development in a particular subarea that differ from impact fees imposed on similar land development in other subareas within the City. 
27.06 - IMPOSITION OF IMPACT FEE . 
(1)  The impact fees set forth in §27.09 of this Ordinance are hereby imposed on all developments and land divisions within the City or any development subarea thereof. 
(2)  No building permit shall be issued for a development unless the impact fees set forth in §27.09 are imposed and calculated pursuant to this Ordinance. Fees shall be payable within 14 days after building permits are issued. 
27.07 - ESTABLISHMENT OF DEVELOPMENT SUBAREAS . 
(1)  Development subareas are established as shown on the Development Subareas Map. Such development subareas will be established consistent with any facility service areas established in the capital improvements plan and public facility needs assessment for each public facility. 
(2)  Additional development subareas or combinations of development subareas may be designated by the City Council as development subareas consistent with the procedure set forth in this Ordinance and with §66.0617, Wis. Stats. 
27.08 - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS PROGRAM BY SUBAREA . 
To service the projected development, the impact fee will be required to fund public facilities as shown on the capital improvements program. 
27.09 - IMPACT FEE SCHEDULES/CALCULATION . (Rep. & recr. #10-O782) 
(1)  RESIDENTIAL/NONRESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT - 5/8 - TO 2-INCH METER. 
(a)  The following fee schedule (Table 1) based upon meter size shall apply to all residential/nonresidential connections with meter sizes of ?-inch up to 2-inch. These fees are a one-time fee and are not subject to a review period. The standard residential meter is the 3/4-inch meter for the purpose of fee calculation. 
TABLE 1 
Meter Sizes (a) (b) (c) (d) ?" and 3/4" 1" 11/2" 2" 2nd Street Lift Station Impact Fee Refer to Table 2 Refer to Table 2 Refer to Table 2 Refer to Table 2 Water Facilities Impact Fee $336 $917 $2,205 $3,663 North Interceptor Impact Fee $2,029 $7,551 $18,159 $30,160  
(Am. #15-O881; #16-O904; #17-O925) 
(b)  The Water Facilities Impact Fee and the North Interceptor Impact Fee may be increased annually based upon the prior year's average interest rate for the Wisconsin Local Government Investment Pool (LGIP) rate. (Am. #15-O881) 
(2)  RESIDENTIAL/NONRESIDENTIAL - 3-INCH METER OR LARGER. 
(a)  Residential/nonresidential connections with a meter size of 3-inch or greater shall be calculated using the estimated water usage supplied by the owner/developer on the appropriate city form divided by the appropriate annualized gallons applicable (definitions §27.04(16)(a), (b) and (c)) to each of the fees in the ordinance to arrive at the number of RECs, and then multiplying the RECs times the appropriate fees in force at the time of calculation. 
1.  The property owner shall submit, on forms provided by the City, a good faith estimation of the intended water and sewer usage for a nonresidential development. 
2.  Based upon the information supplied by the property owner under subsection 1., the City shall calculate the number of RECs for that development by dividing the intended water use by the annualized amount as defined in definitions §27.04(16)(a), (b) or (c). All REC calculations shall be rounded up to the nearest 0.5 REC. An interim fee shall be calculated by multiplying the calculated RECs by the fee schedule as in Table 1 above. 
3.  Since the impact fee determined under subsections 1. and 2., above, is based upon estimated intended usage, the City shall have the right to recalculate the charge based upon actual usage for any 12-month period. At anytime between the first and third anniversary dates of establishment of the nonresidential account, the City may review the account history to determine a highest actual recorded usage in any 12-month period. 
4.  Based upon the information obtained under subsection 3., above, the City shall recalculate the number of RECs and may recalculate the impact fee pursuant to subsection 2., above. If the recalculated charge exceeds that of the original charge, the difference between the recalculated charge and the amount paid for the original charge shall become due and payable at the time the adjustment is made by the current owner of the property. If reviewed pursuant to subsection 3. above, the calculations and billing shall be accomplished within 6 months of the end of the third year. 
(3)  IRRIGATION METERS-COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL USERS. 
(a)  All commercial or industrial users choosing to irrigate their property must install irrigation meters to meter this water use separately. This meter shall be plumbed independent of the domestic meters. 
(b)  A one-time impact fee will be charged for all irrigation meters, payable at the time of permit and calculated based on the square footage of the area to be irrigated as supplied by the property owner. 
(c)  Fee components: 
1.  Water System Impact Fee: $0.01641 per square foot of irrigated area. (Am. #15-O881; #16-O904; #17-O925) 
2.  Reserved. (Rep. #15-O881) 
(4)  REDEVELOPMENT AND/OR INCREASE IN USE. 
(a)  Residential/Nonresidential Development - 2-Inch Meter Size or Less . Where redevelopment does not require an increase in the size of the meter, there will be no charge. Should a redevelopment or increase in use of an existing user require an increase in the size of the meter/service, the charge due would be the difference between the existing meter size and the required meter size as proposed for the development in §27.09(1) (see Table 1). 
(b)  Residential/Nonresidential Development - Meter Sizes 3-Inch and Larger . 
1.  The property owner shall submit, on forms provided by the City, a good faith estimation of the intended water and sewer usage for the residential/nonresidential redevelopment. Existing meter size equivalent flow for the current meter size in use up to 2 inches of the redevelopment site should then be deducted from the proposed intended usage to arrive at the basis for recalculation. If the current meter is 3 inches or larger, the existing use to be deducted shall be based on annual use history. 
2.  Based upon the information supplied by the property owner under subsection 1., the City shall calculate the number of RECs for that redevelopment by dividing the intended water use by the annualized amount as defined in definitions §27.04(16)(a), (b) or (c). All REC calculations shall be rounded up to the nearest 0.5 REC. An interim fee shall be calculated by multiplying the calculated RECs by the fee schedule as in Table 1 above. 
3.  Since the impact fee determined under subsections 1. and 2., above, is based upon estimated intended usage, the City shall have the right to recalculate the charge based upon actual usage for any 12-month period. At any time between the first and third anniversary dates of establishment of a nonresidential account, the City may review the account history to determine the highest actual recorded usage in any 12-month period. 
4.  Based upon the information obtained under subsection 3., the City shall recalculate the number of RECs and may recalculate the impact fee pursuant to subsection 2., above. If the recalculated charge exceeds that of the original charge, the difference between the recalculated charge and the amount paid for the original charge shall become due and payable at the time the adjustment is made by the current owner of the property/development. If reviewed pursuant to subsection 3., above, the calculations and billing shall be accomplished within 6 months of the end of the third year. 
(5)  WATER FACILITIES IMPACT FEE. 
(a)  Facilities . The water facilities (2006) consist of one well, a pump station, and a reservoir. 
(b)  Water Facilities (2006) Impact Fee . For purposes of the water facilities (2006) impact fee under this section, the area subject to the fee shall be all of the area served by the City Water Utility. 
(c)  Residential/Nonresidential Development - 2-Inch Meter Size or Less . For unplatted lands; for undeveloped platted land, the fees shall be determined following guidelines in §27.09(1). 
(d)  Residential/Nonresidential Development - Meter Sizes 3-Inch and Larger . Fees shall be determined following guidelines in §27.09(2). 
(e)  Redevelopment and/or Increase in Use . Fees shall be determined following guidelines in §27.09(3)(a) or (b). 
(6)  NORTH INTERCEPTOR IMPACT FEE. 
(a)  North Interceptor Impact Fee Subarea . For purposes of the North Interceptor Impact Fee imposed under this section, the subarea shall be all land within the North Interceptor sewer service area as identified in Exhibit 2 attached to Ordinance No. 98-0412. 
(b)  Residential/Nonresidential Development - 2-Inch Meter Size or Less . For unplatted lands; for undeveloped platted land, the fees shall be determined as in §27.09(1). 
(c)  Residential/Nonresidential Development - Meter Sizes 3-Inch and Larger . Fees shall be determined following guidelines in §27.09(2). 
(d)  Redevelopment and/or Increase in Use . Fees shall be determined following guidelines as found in §27.09(3)(a) or (b). 
(7)  RESERVED. (Rep. #15-O881) 
(8)  SECOND STREET LIFT STATION SEWER IMPACT FEE. 
(a)  Sewer Impact Fee Subarea . For purposes of the sewer impact fee imposed under this section, the subarea shall be all the land within the Second Street Lift Station sewer service area as identified in Exhibit 1 attached to Ordinance No. 98-0412. 
(b)  Residential/Nonresidential Development - 2-Inch Meter Size or Less . The following fee schedule (Table 2) based upon meter size shall apply to all residential 2-inch meters or less.

(c)  Residential/Nonresidential Development - Meter Sizes 3-Inch or Larger . 
1.  The property owner shall submit, on forms provided by the City, a good faith estimation of the intended water and sewer usage for the nonresidential development. 
2.  Based upon the information supplied by the property owner under subsection 1., the City shall calculate the number of RECs for that development by dividing the intended water use by the annualized amount as defined in definition §27.04(16)(b). All REC calculations shall be rounded up to the nearest 0.5 REC. An interim fee shall be calculated by multiplying the calculated RECs by the fee schedule in Table 2 above. 
3.  Since the impact fee determined under subsections 1. and 2., above, is based upon estimated intended usage, the City shall have the right to recalculate the charge based upon actual usage for any 12-month period. At any time between the first and third anniversary dates of establishment of the nonresidential account, the City may review the account history to determine the highest actual recorded usage in any 12-month period. 
4.  Based upon the information obtained under subsection 3., above, the City shall recalculate the number of RECs and may recalculate the impact fee pursuant to subsection 2., above. If the recalculated charge exceeds that of the original charge, the difference between the recalculated charge and the amount paid for the original charge shall become due and payable at the time the adjustment is made by the current owner of the property/development. If reviewed pursuant to subsection 3., above, the calculations and billing shall be accomplished within 6 months of the end of the third year. 
(d)  Redevelopment and/or Increase in Use . 
1.  Residential/Nonresidential Development - 2-Inch Meter Size or Less. Where redevelopment does not require an increase in the size of the meter, there will be no charge. Should a redevelopment or increase in use of an existing user require an increase in the size of the meter/service, the charge due would be the difference between the existing meter size and the required meter size as proposed for the redevelopment shown in Table 2. 
2.  Residential/Nonresidential Development - Meter Size 3-Inch and Larger. 
a.  The property owner shall submit, on forms provided by the City, a good faith estimation of the intended water and sewer usage for the residential/nonresidential redevelopment. Existing meter size equivalent flow for the current meter size in use up to 2-inch of the redevelopment site should then be deducted from the proposed intended usage to arrive at the basis for recalculation. If the current meter is 3-inch or larger, the existing use to be deducted shall be based on annual use history. 
b.  Based upon the information supplied by the property owner under subsection a., the City shall calculate the number of RECs for that redevelopment by dividing the intended water use by the annualized amount as defined in definitions §27.04(16)(a), (b) and (c). All REC calculations shall be rounded up to the nearest 0.5 REC. An interim fee shall be calculated by multiplying the calculated RECs by the fee schedule as in Table 1 above. 
c.  Since the impact fee determined under subsections a. and b., above, is based upon estimated intended usage, the City shall have the right to recalculate the charge based upon actual usage for any 12-month period. At any time between the first and third anniversary dates of establishment of a nonresidential account, the City may review the account history to determine the highest actual recorded usage in any 12-month period. 
d.  Based upon the information obtained under subsection c., the City shall recalculate the number of RECs and may recalculate the impact fee pursuant to subsection b., above. If the recalculated charge exceeds that of the original charge, the difference between the recalculated charge and the amount paid for the original charge shall become due and payable at the time the adjustment is made by the current owner of the property/development. If reviewed pursuant to subsection c., above, the calculations and billing shall be accomplished within 6 months of the end of the third year. 
(9)  HIGHWAYS AND OTHER TRANSPORTATION FACILITIES IMPACT FEE. (Cr. #05-O627) 
(a)  Highways and Other Transportation Facilities Impact Fee . For purposes of transportation facilities fees imposed under this section, the area subject to the fee shall be all the land within the City. 
(b)  Residential Development. (Am. #08-O733; #15-O881; #16-O904; #17-O925) The highways and other transportation facilities impact fee shall be $113.00 per residential dwelling unit. 
(c)  Nonresidential Development. The highways and other transportation facilities impact fee shall be calculated based on planned building gross floor area according to the fee schedule below. For any properties for which the planned gross floor area is not known at the time that the impact fee is imposed and calculated, the fee shall be calculated based on the gross floor area set forth on the application for a building permit. When actual gross floor area is known, an appropriate charge shall be made if the actual gross floor area is more than what was represented on the building permit application, or credit may be given if the actual gross floor area is less than the gross floor area represented on the building permit application.

(d)  Impact Fee Increase . The impact fee may be increased annually based upon the prior year's average interest rate for the Engineering News Record Construction Cost Index, 20 City Coverage. 
(10)  LAW ENFORCEMENT FACILITIES IMPACT FEE. (Cr. #05-O627) 
(a)  Law Enforcement Facilities Impact Fee . For purposes of law enforcement facilities impact fee imposed under this section, the area subject to the fee shall be all the land within the City. 
(b)  Residential Development. (Am. #08-O733; #15-O881; #16-O904; #17-O925) The law enforcement facilities fee shall be $201.00 per single-family residential dwelling unit and $126.00 per multi-family residential dwelling unit.

For any properties for which the planned gross floor area is not known at the time that the impact fee is imposed and calculated, the fee shall be calculated based on the gross floor area set forth on the application for a building permit. When actual gross floor area is known, an appropriate charge shall be made if the actual gross floor area is more than what was represented on the building permit application, or credit may be given if the actual gross floor area is less than the gross floor area represented on the building permit application.

(12)  PARKS, PLAYGROUNDS, AND LAND FOR ATHLETIC FIELDS IMPACT FEE. (Cr. #05-O627)

27.10 - CALCULATION OF IMPACT FEE . (Am. #10-O782) 
The City shall calculate the impact fee as follows: 
(1)  HIGHWAYS AND OTHER TRANSPORTATION FACILITIES IMPACT FEE. 
(a)  Residential Development . 
1.  Verify the number and type of residential dwelling units. 
2.  Determine the applicable per unit impact fee. 
3.  Multiply the applicable per unit impact fee by the appropriate number of residential dwelling units. 
(b)  Nonresidential Development . See §27.09(5)(c) above. 
(c)  Mixed Use Development . Separately calculate the impact fee as set forth above for each type of development. 
(d)  Redevelopment . 
1.  Calculate the total amount of the impact fee that would be imposed on the property for the redeveloped use. 
2.  Calculate the total amount of the impact fee that would be imposed on the property for its current (predevelopment) use. 
3.  Subtract the amount of the impact fee that would be imposed for the current use from the amount that would be imposed for the redeveloped use. 
(2)  LAW ENFORCEMENT FACILITIES IMPACT FEE. 
(a)  Residential Development . 
1.  Verify the number and type of residential dwelling units. 
2.  Determine the applicable per unit impact fee. 
3.  Multiply the applicable per unit impact fee by the appropriate number of residential dwelling units. 
(b)  Nonresidential Development . See §27.09(6)(c) above. 
(c)  Mixed Use Development . Separately calculate the impact fee as set forth above for each type of development. 
(d)  Redevelopment . 
1.  Calculate the total amount of the impact fee that would be imposed on the property for the redeveloped use. 
2.  Calculate the total amount of the impact fee that would be imposed on the property for its current (predevelopment) use. 
3.  Subtract the amount of the impact fee that would be imposed for the current use from the amount that would be imposed for the redeveloped use. 
(3)  FIRE PROTECTION AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL FACILITIES IMPACT FEE. 
(a)  Residential Development . 
1.  Verify the number and type of residential dwelling units. 
2.  Determine the applicable per unit impact fee. 
3.  Multiply the applicable per unit impact fee by the appropriate number of residential dwelling units. 
(b)  Nonresidential Development . See §27.09(7)(c) above. 
(c)  Mixed Use Development . Separately calculate the impact fee as set forth above for each type of development. 
(d)  Redevelopment . 
1.  Calculate the total amount of the impact fee that would be imposed on the property for the redeveloped use. 
2.  Calculate the total amount of the impact fee that would be imposed on the property for its current (predevelopment) use. 
3.  Subtract the amount of the impact fee that would be imposed for the current use from the amount that would be imposed for the redeveloped use. 
(4)  PARKS, PLAYGROUNDS, AND LAND FOR ATHLETIC FACILITIES IMPACT FEE. 
(a)  Residential Development . 
1.  Verify the number and type of residential dwelling units. 
2.  Determine the applicable per unit impact fee. 
3.  Multiply the applicable per unit impact fee by the appropriate number of residential dwelling units. 
(b)  Nonresidential Development . See §27.09(8)(d) above. 
(c)  Mixed Use Development . Separately calculate the impact fee as set forth above for each type of development. 
(d)  Redevelopment . 
1.  Calculate the total amount of the impact fee that would be imposed on the property for the redeveloped use. 
2.  Calculate the total amount of the impact fee that would be imposed on the property for its current (predevelopment) use. 
3.  Subtract the amount of the impact fee that would be imposed for the current use from the amount that would be imposed for the redeveloped use. 
(e)  Hotel Redevelopment. (Cr. #16-O899) 
1.  Calculate the total amount of the impact fee that would be imposed on the property for the redeveloped use. 
2.  Calculate the total amount of the impact fee that would be imposed on the property for its current (predevelopment) use. 
3.  Subtract the amount of the impact fee that would be imposed for the current use from the amount that would be imposed for the redeveloped use. 
4.  Multiply the amount by .25. 
27.11 - ADMINISTRATION OF IMPACT FEE . 
(1)  COLLECTION OF IMPACT FEE. 
(a)  For all developments, impact fees shall be payable within 14 days after the issuance of a building permit under Chapter 14 of the Municipal Code. 
(b)  The effective date of a building permit is the date on which all impact fees imposed under this chapter are paid in full and unless all impact fees are paid in full within 14 days after issuance as required by §66.0617(6)(g), Wis. Stats., said building permit shall expire 15 days after issuance. 
(c)  For any new development for which impact fees were paid prior to final plat or certified survey map approval, impact fees shall not be imposed as a condition of issuance of a building permit. 
(2)  TRANSFER OF FUNDS TO ACCOUNTING DEPARTMENT. Upon receipt of impact fees, the City Accounting Department shall be responsible for placement of such fees into separate accounts as hereinafter specified. 
(3)  ESTABLISHMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF ACCOUNTS. The City Accounting Department shall establish a separate interest-bearing account for fees collected for each subarea. Interest or income earned by each account shall be credited to that account and shall be used solely for the purposes specified for such account. The City Accounting Department shall maintain records for each such account, as hereinafter specified. 
(4)  MAINTENANCE OF RECORDS. The City Accounting Department shall maintain and keep adequate financial records for each such account, which shall show the source and disbursement of all revenues, which shall account for all moneys received, and which shall ensure that the disbursement of moneys from each account shall be used solely and exclusively for the provision of projects specified in the capital improvements program for the particular development subarea. 
(5)  ANNUAL REVIEW AND MODIFICATION. The City may periodically review the development potential of each subarea and the capital improvements plans and make such modifications as are deemed necessary as a result of: 
(a)  Development occurring in the prior year; 
(b)  Public facilities actually constructed; 
(c)  Changing facility needs; 
(d)  Inflation; 
(e)  Revised cost estimates for public facilities; 
(f)  Changes in the availability of other funding sources applicable to public facility projects; and 
(g)  Such other factors as may be relevant. 
With the exception of annual increases to account for inflation, any impact fee modifications resulting from changes in development potential or capital improvements programs will require a public hearing as described in §27.17. 
27.12 - BONDING OF EXCESS FACILITY PROJECTS . 
Impact fees paid pursuant to this Ordinance shall be restricted to use solely and exclusively for direct financing of public facilities, or as a pledge against bonds, revenue certificates, and other obligations of indebtedness for the cost of public facilities as specified herein. 
27.13 - REFUNDS. 
(1)  The current owner of the property with respect to which the impact fees were imposed may apply for a refund of such fee, along with any interest that has accumulated, as described in §66.0617(8), Wis. Stats., if: 
(a)  For impact fees paid prior to June 13, 2006, the City has failed to provide a public facility serving such property within 10 years of the date of payment of the impact fee for parks, playgrounds and land for athletic facilities and highways and other transportation facilities; Second Street lift station; north interceptor sewer; and north water tower; and within 20 years of the date of payment of the impact fee for law enforcement facilities and fire protection and emergency medical facilities; or 
(b)  For impact fees paid on or after June 13, 2006, the City has failed to use the impact fees within 7 years of the date of the payment of the impact fee for the capital costs for which they were imposed for parks, playgrounds and land for athletic facilities, highways and other transportation facilities, Second Street lift station, north interceptor sewer, north water tower, law enforcement facilities and fire protection and emergency medical facilities. 
(c)  As permitted by §66.0617(9)(b), Wis. Stats., the 7-year time limit for using impact fees that is specified under paragraph (b) may be extended for 3 years if the City adopts a resolution stating that, due to extenuating circumstances or hardship in meeting the 7-year limit, it needs an additional 3 years to use the impact fees that were collected. The resolution shall specify the extenuating circumstances or hardship that led to the need to adopt a resolution under this paragraph. 
(d)  The building permit for which the impact fee has been paid has lapsed for noncommencement of construction; or 
(e)  The project for which a building permit has been issued has been altered in a manner which has resulted in a decrease in the amount of the impact fee due; or 
(f)  As otherwise authorized in this Ordinance. 
(2)  A written petition for refund must be filed with the City Administrator or his/her designee within one year of the event giving rise to the right to claim a refund. Failure to do so as provided herein shall be considered a waiver of the right to claim a refund under this chapter. 
(3)  Within 10 business days of the filing date of a petition for refund, the City Administrator shall forward a copy of the petition for refund to the appropriate department head. Within 30 business days of receipt, the appropriate department head shall submit a written report and recommendation to the City Administrator. The City Administrator shall review this report and make a written recommendation to the City Council. Within 45 days of the date of the City Administrator's written recommendation, the City Council shall adopt a resolution denying, approving, or approving in part the refund petition. 
(4)  If the petitioner wishes to appeal the decision of the City Council, the petitioner may commence an action in the Waukesha County Circuit Court seeking review of the Council's decision within 30 days after the date on which the Council adopted the resolution with respect to the petition for refund. 
27.14 - APPEALS . 
(1)  NOTICE OF APPEAL. Any developer upon whom an impact fee has been imposed may contest the amount, collection or use of the impact fee by filing a Notice of Appeal to the City Council. The Notice of Appeal shall be filed with the City Clerk within 30 days of the date of the determination therein appealed. The Notice of Appeal shall state in detail the relief sought by the developer and any legal or factual basis for the relief requested; and shall include all supporting documentation upon which the developer relies in making the appeal. 
(2)  APPEAL BOND. If the Notice of Appeal is accompanied by a bond or other sufficient surety satisfactory to the City Attorney in an amount equal to the impact fee due, as calculated by the City Administrator or the Administrator's designee, and all other requirements have been satisfied, the building permit may be issued. The filing of an appeal shall not stay the collection of the impact fee due unless a bond or other sufficient surety has been filed. 
(3)  REVIEW BY THE CITY COUNCIL. 
(a)  Within 10 business days of the date of filing of the Notice of Appeal, the City Administrator shall forward a copy of the Notice of Appeal to the appropriate department head. Within 30 business days of receipt, the appropriate department head shall submit a written report and recommendation to the City Administrator. The City Administrator shall review this report and make a written recommendation to the City Council. 
(b)  Within 45 days of the date of the City Administrator's written recommendation, the City Council shall adopt a resolution denying, approving, or approving in part the appeal. 
(4)  REVIEW BY CIRCUIT COURT. If the developer wishes to appeal the decision of the City Council, the developer may commence an action by certiorari in the Waukesha County Circuit Court seeking review of the Council's decision within 30 days after the date on which the Council adopted the resolution with respect to the developer's appeal. 
27.15 - EFFECT OF IMPACT FEE ON ZONING AND SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS . 
This Ordinance shall not affect, in any manner, the permissible use of property, density of development, design, and improvement standards and requirements, or any other aspect of the development of land or provision of public improvements subject to the zoning and subdivision regulations or other regulations of the City, which shall be operative and remain in full force and effect without limitation with respect to all such development. 
27.16 - IMPACT FEE AS ADDITIONAL AND SUPPLEMENTAL REQUIREMENT . 
Except as required by §66.0617(6)(d), Wis. Stats., the impact fees imposed under this chapter are additional and supplemental to, and not in substitution of, any other requirements imposed by the City on the development of land or the issuance of building permits. 
27.17 - AMENDMENTS . 
(1)  PUBLIC HEARING. Before enacting an ordinance that amends Chapter 27, the City Council shall hold a public hearing on the proposed ordinance or amendment. 
(2)  NOTICE. Pursuant to §66.0617(3), Wis. Stats., notice of the public hearing referred to in the preceding section shall be published as a Class 1 notice under Ch. 985, Wis. Stats., and shall specify where a copy of the proposed ordinance or amendment and the public needs assessment may be obtained. 
(3)  PUBLIC FACILITIES NEEDS ASSESSMENT. Before enacting an ordinance that imposes impact fees or amending an ordinance that imposes impact fees by revising the amount of the fee or altering the public facilities for which impact fees may be imposed, a needs assessment shall be prepared and made available for public inspection and copying as required by §66.0617(4), Wis. Stats. 
27.18 - CREDITS. 
(1)  A property owner may elect to construct a public facility listed in the Capital Improvements Plan for which an impact fee has been imposed. If the property owner elects to construct such a public facility, the property owner must enter into an agreement with the City prior to issuance of any building permit. In any such agreement, the City shall reasonably provide for credits for other past or future monetary or nonmonetary contributions by the developer to the construction of the same public facility, as follows: 
(a)  Present value of amounts contributed within the last 3 years for any land dedications, physical improvements, or financial contributions made for the construction of the public facility; 
(b)  Present land dedications and physical improvements made for the construction of the public facility; 
(c)  Future land dedications, physical improvements made for the construction of the public facility for a period not to exceed 3 years. 
(2)  In no event shall credit provided under subsection (1) be greater than the otherwise applicable fee. 
(3)  No credits shall be given for the construction of local on-site facilities required by zoning, subdivision, or other City requirements or which are not included in the capital improvements program. 
27.19 - PENALTY. 
In addition to any other remedy which the City may have for any violation of any portion of this chapter, any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a penalty as provided in Chapter 25 of the City Municipal Code. Each violation, and each day a violation continues or occurs, shall constitute a separate offense. This section shall not preclude the City from maintaining any appropriate action to prevent or abate a violation of this chapter. 
CHAPTER 28 - JOINT STORMWATER UTILITY 
28.01 General Provisions 28.02 Application 28.03 Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District Commission 28.04 Severability of Provision 28.05 Violations and Penalties  

28.01 - GENERAL PROVISIONS . (Cr. #03-0567) 
(1)  FINDINGS AND NECESSITY. The City of Oconomowoc and the Town of Summit find that the management of stormwater and other surface water discharges within the City and the Town is a matter that affects the health, safety and welfare of the area, its citizens and businesses, and others in the surrounding area. Failure to effectively manage stormwater affects the sanitary sewer system operations of the area by, among other things, increasing the likelihood of infiltration and inflow in the sanitary sewer system. In addition, surface water runoff may create erosion of lands, threaten businesses and residences with water damage, and create environmental damage to the lakes, streams and other water bodies within and adjacent to the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District. Surface water runoff, if not controlled, will impact not only on the aforementioned lakes and streams and other water bodies, but will also degrade the groundwater within the District and in areas adjacent thereto. The cost of operating and maintaining the Pabst Farms joint stormwater management system and financing the necessary repairs, replacements, improvements, and extensions thereof should, to the extent practicable, be allocated in relationship to the impact on and services received from the system. In order to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public, the City and the Town hereby exercise their respective authorities to establish a stormwater utility and establish the rates for stormwater management services. 
(2)  AUTHORITY. This ordinance is adopted under the authority granted by Chs. 60, 62 and 66, Wis. Stats., including, but not limited to, the following sections: §60.627, §62.11(5), §62.16, §62.175, §62.18, §66.0627, §66.0809, §66.0811, and §66.0821. 
(3)  ESTABLISHMENT. 
(a)  There is hereby established the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater Utility. The operation of the stormwater utility shall be under the supervision of the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District Commission. 
(b)  The City and the Town have contracted to enact this ordinance as a uniform method of regulation of surface water management throughout the District. The municipalities will enact the ordinance as a regulatory ordinance applicable to the area of each municipality that falls within the legally defined District. 
(4)  COMMISSION AUTHORITY. The Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District Commission, through the Stormwater Utility, may acquire, construct, lease, own, operate, maintain, extend, expand, replace, clean, dredge, repair, conduct, manage and finance such facilities as are deemed by the Commission to be proper and reasonably necessary for a system and storm and surface water management. These facilities may include, without limitation by enumeration, surface and underground drainage facilities, sewers, water courses, retaining walls and ponds, and such other facilities as will support a stormwater management system. 
(5)  INTERGOVERNMENTAL AGREEMENT ADOPTED BY REFERENCE. 
(a)  The Intergovernmental Agreement entered into by the Town and the City attached hereto as Exhibit A (hereinafter the "Intergovernmental Agreement"), and all future modifications and amendments thereto, are hereby adopted by reference as though set forth in full in this ordinance. 
(b)  Those property owners to whom this ordinance applies are required to comply with the terms of the Intergovernmental Agreement. A violation of or failure to comply with any provision of said Agreement shall be considered a violation of this Ordinance No. 03-0567. 
28.02 - APPLICATION . (Cr. #03-0567) 
(1)  [APPLICATION.] The application of Ordinance No. 03-0567, its rules, regulations and rates shall apply to all individuals, firms, corporations and institutions owning property within the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District. 
(2)  STORMWATER MANAGEMENT PLAN AND FACILITIES REQUIRED. No owner of property within the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District shall proceed with any development or redevelopment, or with the final division of property for residential purposes by means of platting or certified survey map, unless said property owner has submitted to and has received approval of a site-specific stormwater management plan by the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District Commission. Property owners developing, redeveloping or dividing property shall also comply with the District regulations as defined in the Intergovernmental Agreement. 
(3)  PERMIT REQUIREMENTS. No property owner shall undertake a land development, redevelopment or final residential property division activity subject to the requirements of this ordinance without first receiving a permit from the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District Commission. 
(4)  APPLICATION AND FEE. Permit applications shall be made on a form provided by the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District Commission. The application must be accompanied by the site-specific stormwater management plan required under the provisions of this ordinance and District regulations and a nonrefundable permit administration fee in an amount as from time to time established by the Commission. 
(5)  PERMIT COMPLIANCE. No construction as defined in the Intergovernmental Agreement shall be undertaken prior to the issuance of a permit by the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District Commission, and all construction must be performed according to the approved site-specific stormwater management plan. 
28.03 - PABST FARMS JOINT STORMWATER DISTRICT COMMISSION . (Cr. #03-0567) 
(1)  CREATION OF THE COMMISSION. The parties have established a Commission, known as the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District Commission, by the Intergovernmental Agreement. 
(2)  COMPOSITION. The composition of the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District Commission, the authority of the Commission, and the method of operation by the Commission shall be as set forth in the Intergovernmental Agreement. 
28.04 - SEVERABILITY OF PROVISION . (Cr. #03-0567) 
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, or phrase of this ordinance is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional by reason of any decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of any other section, subsection, sentence, clause, or phrase, or portion thereof. 
28.05 - VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES . (Cr. #03-0567) 
(1)  Any person who fails to comply with any of the provisions of this joint ordinance, or with an order of the City, Town, or the Pabst Farm Stormwater District Commission issued pursuant to this ordinance, shall be liable to the City, Town, or the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District Commission for any expense, loss or damage occasioned by such violation, including reasonable attorney fees and other expenses of litigation; and upon conviction for any violation of this ordinance, shall be subject to a forfeiture of not less than $100.00 nor more than $2,500.00 per violation, plus damages. Each day a condition is allowed to exist which is contrary to all or any part of this ordinance, including the Intergovernmental Agreement adopted by reference herein, shall constitute a separate violation. Change of ownership or occupancy of premises delinquent under the provisions of this ordinance shall not be cause for reducing or eliminating charges due and penalties for violations. 
(2)  In addition to the court proceedings and penalties described in the foregoing subsection of this ordinance, whenever a person violates any provision of said ordinance or fails to comply with any order of the City, Town, or the Pabst Farms Joint Stormwater District Commission, the City, Town or Commission may order that an action be commenced on behalf of the City, Town or Commission in the County Court for Waukesha County for the purpose of obtaining an injunction restraining the person violating this ordinance or failing to comply with the order, from further violating this ordinance, or any rule or regulation of the Commission. 
CHARTER ORDINANCE 
AN ORDINANCE TO PROVIDE FOR THE MANNER OF SELECTING AN ASSESSOR FOR THE CITY OF OCONOMOWOC. 
    The Common Council of the City of Oconomowoc do ordain as follows: 
    Section 1. From and after the date of termination of the term of office of the present City Assessor, the office of City Assessor in the City of Oconomowoc shall be filled by appointment of the Mayor subject to the confirmation of the Council. 
    Section 2. All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
    Section 3. This ordinance shall take effect and shall be in full force and effect sixty days following its passage and publication. 
/s/ Frank J. Dumbeck, 
      Mayor   /s/ Fred C. Behrend, 
      Clerk   Passed: 1/3/50 
Published: 1/5/50 
CHARTER ORDINANCE 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE CHARTER OF THE CITY OF OCONOMWOC, WISCONSIN 
    The Common Council of the City of Oconomowoc do ordain as follows: 
    That section of the Original Charter of the City of Oconomowoc entitled "Officers, Their Election, Appointment, Qualifications, Compensation; Vacancies" is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    Section 1. From and after the date of termination of the term of office of the present City Treasurer, the office of Treasurer in the City of Oconomowoc shall be filled by appointment by Mayor, subject to confirmation by the Common Council. 
    Section 2. The offices of City Treasurer and City Assessor may be held by the same person. 
    Section 3. All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
    Section 4. This ordinance shall take effect sixty days following its passage and publication. 
/s/ Frank J. Dumbeck, 
      Mayor   /s/ Edgar E. Otto, 
      Clerk       Published: 10/2/51

A CHARTER ORDINANCE RELATING 
TO THE SELECTION AND TENURE OF CITY 
ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICIALS 
    The Common Council of the City of Oconomowoc do ordain as follows: 
    Section I. The City of Oconomowoc hereby elects not to be governed by those portions of Section 62.09(3)(b) and (5)(b) of the Wisconsin Statutes, relating to the method of selection and tenure of the City Assessor, City Clerk, City Treasurer, Director of Public Works, City Engineer, Superintendent of Parks and Recreation Director, which are in conflict with this ordinance. 
    Section II. Hereafter, instead of being appointed annually, by the Mayor and approved by the Council, the City Assessor, City Clerk, City Treasurer, Director of Public Works, City Engineer and Director of Recreation, shall be appointed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation by the majority vote of the members elect of the Common Council for a term as provided in Section III. 
    Section III. The said City Assessor, City Clerk, City Treasurer, Director of Public Works, City Engineer and Recreation Director, shall hold office for an indefinite term, subject to removals provided by law. Tenure shall not apply to any person appointed to any of the above positions during the initial one (1) year of their employment which shall be considered a probationary period. The Common Council may, by resolution, designate additional full time supervisory personnel as being eligible for tenure status under this ordinance. 
    Section IV. This ordinance shall apply to those individuals holding a term of office at the present time, which term has not yet expired. 
    Section V. This is a charter ordinance which shall take effect sixty (60) days after its passage and publication, unless within such sixty (60) days a referendum petition shall be filed as provided by Section 66.01 of the Wisconsin Statutes, in which event this ordinance shall not take effect until submitted to a referendum and approved by a majority of the voters voting thereon. 
/s/ H. O. Hughes   /s/ Bergman, City Clerk   Adopted 6/6/72 
Published 6/15/72
